FACT SHEET
PUBLIC ENCRYPTION MANAGEMENT
The President has approved a directive on ""Public Encryption
Management.""  The directive provides for the following:
Advanced telecommunications and commercially available encryption
are part of a wave of new computer and communications technology.
Encryption products scramble information to protect the privacy of
communications and data by preventing unauthorized access.
Advanced telecommunications systems use digital technology to
rapidly and precisely handle a high volume of communications.
These advanced telecommunications systems are integral to the
infrastructure needed to ensure economic competitiveness in the
information age.
Despite its benefits
frustrate lawful government electronic surveillance.  Sophisticated
encryption can have this effect in the United States.  When
exported abroad
column2: it can be used to thwart foreign intelligence

column1: activities critical to our national interests.  In the past
been possible to preserve a government capability to conduct
electronic surveillance in furtherance of legitimate law
enforcement and national security interests
protecting the privacy and civil liberties of all citizens.  As
encryption technology improves
innovative approaches.
In the area of communications encryption
developed a microcircuit that not only provides privacy through
encryption that is substantially more robust than the current
government standard
column2: but also permits escrowing of the keys needed

column1: to unlock the encryption.  The system for the escrowing of keys
will allow the government to gain access to encrypted information
only with appropriate legal authorization.
To assist law enforcement and other government agencies to collect
and decrypt
information
column2: I hereby direct the following action to be taken:

column1: INSTALLATION OF GOVERNMENT-DEVELOPED MICROCIRCUITS
The Attorney General of the United States
shall request manufacturers of communications hardware which
incorporates encryption to install the U.S. government-developed
key-escrow microcircuits in their products.  The fact of law
enforcement access to the escrowed keys will not be concealed from
the American public.  All appropriate steps shall be taken to
ensure that any existing or future versions of the key-escrow
microcircuit are made widely available to U.S. communications
hardware manufacturers
column2: consistent with the need to ensure the

column1: security of the key-escrow system.  In making this decision
not intend to prevent the private sector from developing
government from approving
are equally effective in assuring both privacy and a secure key-
escrow system.
KEY-ESCROW
The Attorney General shall make all arrangements with appropriate
entities to hold the keys for the key-escrow microcircuits
installed in communications equipment.  In each case
holder must agree to strict security procedures to prevent
unauthorized release of the keys.  The keys shall be released only
to government agencies that have established their authority to
acquire the content of those communications that have been
encrypted by devices containing the microcircuits.  The Attorney
General shall review for legal sufficiency the procedures by which
an agency establishes its authority to acquire the content of such
communications.
PROCUREMENT AND USE OF ENCRYPTION DEVICES
The Secretary of Commerce
U.S. agencies
column2: shall initiate a process to write standards to

column1: facilitate the procurement and use of encryption devices fitted
with key-escrow microcircuits in federal communications systems
that process sensitive but unclassified information.  I expect this
process to proceed on a schedule that will permit promulgation of
a final standard within six months of this directive. "

518|"an excellent automatic can be found in the subaru legacy.  it switches to
sport"" mode when the electronics figure it
the switch.. which is the proper way to do it
mode entail?  several things:
1) revving to red line (or to the rev limiter in the case of the legacy)
2) delayed upshifts.  (i.e. if you lift off briefly
low gear.  this is handy if you are charging through corners and
would like to do without the distraction of upshifts when there's
another curve approaching)
3) part throttle downshifts
column2: based on the *speed* at which the pedal is

column1: depressed
column2: rather than the *position* of the pedal.  modern

column1: electronics can measure this very easily and switch to sport mode.
this is wonderful if you want to charge through a green light about
to turn red.  my audi senses this very well and can downshift on as
little as half throttle if my right foot is fast enough.
also
column2: i think that a smart automatic can deliver better gas mileage

column1: than a dumb driver with a stick
column2: all else being equal.. remember that

column1: the idea of a stick being more economical than an automatic makes a
big assumption that the driver is smart enough to know what gear to
use for each situation.. how many times have you ridden with an
inattentive driver cruising on the highway at 55/65 in 4th gear (of a
5 speed)?
how many % of people who drive manuals *really* know what the best
gear to use is for every conceivable situation?  i'm sure there will
be some who know
column2: but i suspect that a chip controlled automatic with

column1: all possible scenario/ratio combinations stored in ROM is likely to do
better.  i can also say that all my previous assumptions were proved
wrong after i got a car with instantaneous mpg readout... high gear
low revs and wide open throttle is more economical than low gear
revs and small throttle opening.  the explanation is quite simple if
one sits down to think about it
column2: but not that obvious at first sight.

One of the principal functions I look for when considering a DSO is
whether you can turn interpolation off. The other important feature
is to disable repetitive waveform acquisition i.e. being able to lock
the instrument into real time capture mode.
I agree with you here. The only consolation is that manufacturers are
_beginning_ to pay attention to ergonomics when designing the menus.
However
column3: it seems that first time scope users (our students)

column1: seem to adjust to menus easier than navigating around the twenty or
more knobs required of a ""real"" scope :-)
This is one area that newer DSOs are addressing. I recently evaluated
the latest box from Tek - their TDS320 - which seems to be a worthy
alternative to a standard 100MHz analogue CRO. This instrument has
a 100MHz
column3: meaning that it is _always_ in real time

column1: capture mode. The pricing also matches equivalent analogue scopes in
the range. The downer is that the instrument uses menus again
least they appear to be logically laid out.
One more thing about the new
tend to use digital rotary encoders as knobs now. This is a vast improvement
over the old oak switch. The single most common cause of failure in our
scopes (other than students blowing up inputs!) is mechanical wear on these
switches. I look at the new panels as a great step toward increasing the
longevity of the instruments.
JohnH

Stop! Hold it! You have a few problems here. Official history says that
the first accusations of homosexuality in the SA came from OUTSIDE of the Nazi
party
column2: long BEFORE the Nazis ever came to power. So this objection is a red

column1: herring
column2: even if established history is wrong on this point. Moreover

column1: the histories I've read ever made mention of Hitler or anyone else ever using
homosexuality as a pretext for purging Roehm. A point I saw reiterated was that
Hitler and the party covered up these accusations. If you are going to accuse
official history of being a fabrication
column2: you should at least get your facts

column1: right. The pretext for purging Roehm was that he was planning to use the SA in
a coup against Hitler. Nowhere is there mention of using allegations of
homosexuality as a pretext for the purge
is possible that the histories I've read have not mentioned this
it - would it be in Hitler's best interest to admit to the world that his
former right hand man was a homosexual?).
Anyway
column3: it is always possible that I have missed references

column1: to the Nazis making use of charges of homosexuality against the SA after the
night of the long knives - but this does not prove that they were false. Even
the Nazis could tell the truth when it was to their advantage. In any case
this does not deal with accusations of homosexuality in the SA during the
Ah
column2: yes. I forgot this was being posted to alt.conspiracy. I can smell the

column1: paranoia from here. Since the Nazis never officially charged Roehm with
homosexuality (at least
column2: not according to what I've read)

column1: what tainted ""evidence"" you are talking about. Since the accusations were made
by persons outside of the Nazi party
column2: long before it came to power

column1: accusations were common knowledge to journalists and others in Germany in the

column2: just how would it be possible for the Nazis to go back in

column1: time and plant ""tainted"" evidence? How exactly does one doctor newspapers
which were circulated around the world
obvious? What actual incidences of Nazi doctoring evidence on this matter
do you know about? And what about the testimony of people who were involved in
these matters
column2: some of whom were not Nazis? And what is the point of making a

column1: false accusation of homosexuality if you do not publicize it? Since the point
here seems to be to discredit established history
falls on the revisionist. The revisionists had better do their homework
before making accusations. Otherwise they simply look like conspiracy nuts.
This is just about the *only* thing we agree on.
I suspect that the notion that there might have been bad people - Roehm and
his SA buddies - who were homosexuals must disturb some people. The feeling
seems to be that if a nasty individual is accused of homosexuality
must be an attempt to bash homosexuals. This fear - often justified - is what
lies behind this distrust of official history
column2: or so it seems to me. But this

column1: is not a good justification for trashing accepted accounts of this subject. If
you really think that historians are so incompetent
and ask where they got their sources on this subject
their footnotes? I'm a graduate student in history. Writing to professors and
tracking down sources is old hat. But my time is limited and this is not my
specialty - and neither you nor anyone else have said anything that would
cast one shred of doubt on existing evidence. I'm not going to waste my time
trying to debunk someone's paranoia. Do the research yourself.
Given that you already consider all evidence ""tainted""
constitute concrete particulars? And since when have concrete particulars been
considered ""shrewd guesses""?
I suggest that those who do not trust popular historians (Irving et al) -
historians writing for a popular audience do not
footnotes - should try instead reading academic historians
provide footnotes to all their sources in immmense detail. This is the place
to start looking. Assuming that one really wants to know the truth.
I'll bet the folks on alt.pagan are tired of this subject already. My
apologies - we seem to have gone off on a bit of a tangent. I forget which gods
are responsible for keeping strings within appropriate newsgroup subject
boundaries..."

REQUEST FOR IDEAS FOR APPLICATIONS OF REMOTE SENSING DATABASES
VIA THE INTERNET
NASA is planning to expand the domain of users of its Earth and space science
data.  This effort will:
o   Use the evolving infrastructure of the U.S. Global Change Research
Program including the Mission To Planet Earth (MTPE) and the Earth
Observing System Data and Information System (EOSDIS) Programs.
o   Use the Internet
column2: particularly the High Performance Computing and

column1: Communications Program's NREN (National Research and Education
Network)
column2: as a means of providing access to and distribution of

column1: science data and images and value added products.
o   Provide broad access to and utilization of remotely sensed images in
cooperation with other agencies (especially NOAA
DOI/USGS
o   Support remote sensing image and data users and development
communities.
The user and development communities to be included (but not limited to) as
part of this effort are educators
television weather forecasters)
specialists
aqua business.
This program will be initiated in 1994.  Your assistance is requested to
identify potential applications of remote sensing images and data.  We would
like your ideas for potential application areas to assist with development of
the Implementation Plan.
PLEASE NOTE: THIS IS NOT A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.
We are seeking your ideas in these areas:
(1)  Potential commercial use of remote sensing data and images;
(2)  Potential noncommercial use of remote sensing data and images in
education (especially levels K-12) and other noncommercial areas;
(3)  Types of on-line capabilities and protocols to make the data more
accessible;
(4)  Additional points of contacts for ideas; and
(5)  Addresses and names  from whom to request proposals.
For your convenience

May 5

attachments please
FAX:   Ernie Lucier

directory ~ftp/pub/RSDWG on orion.nasa.gov.  Please indicate the format.

RTF.

[In the following I'm mostly playing ""devil's advocate"".  I'm not
advocating either position.  My concern is that people understand that
it's possible to see these passages in different ways.  It's possible
to see eternal destruction as just that -- destruction.  Rev often
uses the term ""second death"".  The most obvious understanding of that
would seem to be final extinction.  The problem is that the NT speaks
both of eternal punishment and of second death.  I.e. it uses terms
that can be understood either way.  My concern here is not to convince
you of one view or the other
column2: but to help people understand that

column1: there's a wide enough variety of images that it's possible to
understand them either way.  As Tom Albrecht commented
point is to do our best to keep people out of the eternal fire
whatever the details.  (To make things more interesting
implies that the damned don't get resurrected at all.  Presumably
they just stay dead. -- yes I'm aware that it's possible to
understand this passage in a non-literal way.)
2 Peter 2:4-ff is talking about angels
in hell until the final judgement.  This isn't eternal punishement.
Matthew 25:31-46 talks about sending the cursed into eternal fire
prepared for the devil and his angels.  The fact that the fire is
eternal doesn't mean that people will last in its flames forever.
Particularly interesting is the comment about the fire having been
prepared for the devil and his angels.  Rev 20 and 21 talk about the
eternal fire as well.  They say that the beast and the false prophet
will be tormented forever in it.  When talking about people being
thrown into it (20:13-14)
column2: it is referred to as ""the second death"".

column1: This sounds more like extinction than eternal torment.  Is is possible
that the fire has different effects on supernatural entities such as
the devil
2 Thessalonians 1:6-10 similarly
This is not necessarily eternal torment.  This one can clearly be
understood either way
column2: but I think it's at least possible to think

column1: that everlasting is being used to contrast the kind of destruction
that can occur in this life with the final destruction that occurs in
eternity.
2 Thessalonians 2:8 again talks about destruction.
Revelation 21:6-8: see comment above
Revelation 14:9-12 is probably the best of the quotes.  Even there
it doesn't explicitly say that the people suffer forever.  It says
that the smoke (and presumably the fire) is eternal
there is no respite from it.  But it doesn't say that the people
are tormented forever.
Psalm 9:17:  I don't see that it says anything relevant to this issue."

walked another 15 to 20 yards I heard the screech of automobile brakes
behind me. I turned my head toward the sound. It was a light blue GAZ-24
Volga. I see that the people who were standing there have gone over to the
car. A man and a woman get out. The man is expensively dressed
and the woman has a raincoat on. She doesn't have anything on her head
her hair is let down
45 years old. They get something out of the trunk. The people start to help
them. I become curious just what are they pulling out of there?
When I got up close I heard them turn something on. I didn't see what it was
but it was probably a tape recorder. They put it on the ground near the
Eternal Flame honoring the 26 Baku Commissars and formed a tight circle
around it. I ask

leading? We came out on Lenin Square. At the square the SK club is on one
side
column2: and the City Party Committee is on the other. I went toward the square

column1: and heard noise and shouting
column2: as though the whole town had turned out. There

column1: was some sort of a rally going on. I go closer and hear exclamations
I heard both anti-Armenian and anti-Soviet appeals. ""We don't need
perestroika
column2: we want to go on living like we have been."" Now what did they

column1: mean by ""living like we have been?"" The Azerbaijanis work like everyone else.
But too many people live at the expense of the government and at the expense
of others. Speculation
column3: and cheating go on all the time. And not just

column1: in Azerbaijan
anywhere else like I have in Azerbaijan.
Now at this rally someone says that they should go around to the Armenians'
apartments and drive them out
column2: beat them and drive them out. True

column1: hear them say ""kill them"" over the microphone
drive them out."" I stayed at the square a few minutes longer. First one
another are going up onto the stage
column2: and no one tries to stop the crowd. Off

column1: to the side of the crowd there were small groups of three or four people
I think they were MVD [Ministry of Internal Affairs] or State Security KGB.
There were also uniformed policemen there
column2: but I didn't see any of them try

column1: to pacify the crowd. New people kept coming up onto the stage.
Well I had finally decided that this could end badly: This was no
demonstration
column2: and I had to protect my family.

column1: I left the Square to return home and suddenly noticed a truck. It was next
to the City Party Committee
column3: it stood next to the tai-

column1: lor's shop there
column4: wooden panels. I see that some-

column1: thing is being unloaded
column2: crates of some sort. I decided to go look because

column1: after all those appeals I was apprehensive and thought there might be weapons
in there. They pulled the crates out onto the square
Party Committee
column2: but toward the SK club. And when I went right up to them I

column1: saw that they were cases of vodka. There were two people handing down the
cases from the bed of the truck
column2: and on the ground there were many people

column1: to 20. They were handing them down from the truck and each case was carried
off by two people. Two people
column2: one case of vodka. And there was a man standing

column1: right next to the truck and he was handing out roundish black lumps
about the size of a fist
column2: maybe a little bigger or smaller. It was anasha.

column1: When I passed next to that person
column2: he stood with his side to me. There was

column1: about a yard and a half between us
column2: and two people were standing near him. He

column1: has a package in his hand
column2: and he's pulling out anasha and handing it out. I

column1: have never smoked it myself. Once I tried it for fun
column2: but I've seen a lot of

column1: people smoke it
column3: and I know what it is. I strolled

column1: around and no one asked me who I was or what I was doing there.
Before I got to the Glass Bazaar I heard more howling
I turned around and saw them running. Well I'll just keep on going like I am
I thought. When they caught up with me I saw that they were carrying flags.
And I recognized the person who was carrying the flag on my side of the
street. He's a young guy
column2: 21 or 22 years old. He was carrying a red flag

column1: which had ""Ermeni oryum"" written on it in Azerbaijani
Armenians!"" That guy used to live off the same courtyard as us. I don't really
know what his name is
column2: but I know his father very well. His father's name is

column1: Rafik; he used to be a cook
column2: and then became head chef. He used to have a dark

column1: blue Zhiguli van
column2: then he sold it and now he has a white Zhiguli 06. His

column1: family
column3: lived on the same courtyard as we did. Our building was on

column1: Narimanov Street
column2: and theirs was on the Street of the 26 Baku Commissars;

column1: their apartment was in the far entryway
left. Now Rafik's little brother lives there
new apartment either in the forth or eighth microdistrict. In a word
was carrying a flag that said ""Death to Armenians!"" I was surprised because
before this I had gotten the impression that all of this nonsense was being
done not by people from Sumgait
column2: but by Azerbaijanis from Agdam and Kafan.

column1: Well anyway I went home. My wife was upset. I told her
they're young kids
column2: they've just gotten all whooped up."" Naturally I didn't

column1: want her to get overly upset. After a while a new surge of crowd went by. And
this time they were breaking glass. I could hear it breaking
see where. Well I think
column3: the machine's in motion. They weren't

column1: handing out that vodka and anasha for nothing. I didn't see people drinking
and smoking on the spot
column2: but they certainly hadn't unloaded the vodka and

column1: hashish to put in a store window!
So the thought flashed through my head that the machine was running
would stop them now
the police were there
column2: I saw them. And it's not just that the police weren't

column1: breaking them up
column3: they were having a good time.

column1: True
column2: at the time I couldn't even imagine that under our government

column1: vaunted leadership--and I'm not afraid to say these words: so many people
died
column3: and how many abominations there were!--I

column1: couldn't imagine that under our much-vaunted authorities
column2: and if I were to be

column1: specific
column2: I would say under the much-touted authorities in our city of

column1: Sumgait
column2: I couldn't imagine that such things could take place.

column1: When they started breaking glass I told my wife and son: ""Let's go upstairs.""
We went to our neighbors
column3: on the fourth floor. And in the

column1: evening
column2: when those crowds started going past again

column1: I stopped at ""The Corner
column2: a place called that right next to the bazaar. I

column1: look and see a crowd on the run. And there
column2: a few yards from the entrance to

column1: the bazaar
column2: are three respectable-looking men of around

column1: The crowd was running and one of the three waved with his arm and pointed
toward the bazaar. And then the whole crowd
column2: as though it were one person

column1: wheeled and raced toward the bazaar. And not a soul went past those three
though it were off limits! Well everything got all churned up
noise
column2: and the glass was flying again.

column1: We spent the night at the neighbors'. My apartment was on the first floor
there was really no way to defend yourself there.
In the morning I went out to buy bread and to see what was happening in town.
On the way I saw someone hunched up
column2: still. I never found out who it was or

column1: what happened to him. There were 10 to 15 people standing near him. I got the
bread and on my way back
column2: they had gathered around the person who was lying

column1: there hunched up
column2: sort of enclosing him; because of the way they were standing

column1: you couldn't even see him.
That was on the morning of February 28. Everyone knows the rest.
May 17
Yerevan

Volume I

not competent with it
column2: but it is not as opaque as I had thought).  It turns

column1: out that while the Index for the Bauer-Arndt-Gingrich ""Greek Lexicon"" renders
each verse in order
column2: each word within a verse is put in greek alphabetical

column1: order.  Thus while the the meaning of the verse is decipherable
far from clear.  On the other hand
things a lot more comprehendable.  And yes
column2: the word for field in Acts 1:18 is

column1: indeed ""chorion.""
Now I've checked several Greek-English lexicons:
""Greek English Lexicon of the New Testament
""Robinson's Greek and English Lexicon of the New Testament""
""Greek English Lexicon of the New Testament
""Word study Concordance
""A Greek English Lexicon of the New Testament and other
early Christian Writings
""The New Analytical Greek Lexicon
In each case the meaning of the word Chorion was given variously as:
A space
land
Nowhere do any of these books mention anything about ""grave."" As some of these
books go into great detail
column2: I would be very surprised to find that these books

column1: are all inadequate and Mr Archer is the only competent scholar in Greek.  I
think it more likely that Mr Archer's investigations into ""contradictions"" to
be once again
is again shown worthless as an expert witness (By the way Mr DeCenso
have honorably presented my results on this matter
column2: even if I had found them

column1: to support Mr Archer's contentions).
By the way
agros
column2: the word used in Matthew 27 to describe the field bought.  The word

column1: agros"" is defined as ""a field in the country."" Chorion is specifically noted
as a synonym to agros.  This is significant
column2: as it is evidence of how silly

column1: Bullinger's exegisis was
column2: which stated that the word for ""field"" in Matthew

column1: (ie: agros) is different from the word for ""field"" in Acts (ie: chorion)
thus we must be talking about two different fields (Of course you already
admit how stupid Bullinger's exegisis is
column2: but this was a small serendipity

column1: which drives the point home).
So as of now
column2: unless Mr DeCenso show compelling reasons to believe otherwise

column1: (eg: a reputable scholar with reputable references)
particular issue closed.  See Mr DeCenso
column2: now you can go on to answer

column1: questions about the denials of Peter
the fact that the author of Matthew quoted from the wrong prophet in
discussing the ""Potter's Field.""
Later

One observation is that people have significantly different personalities
(no question on this) which seem to be essentially in-born.  With respect
to church attendance and participation
other people have real difficulty with this because they prefer a more
solitary and contemplative lifestyle - that is
confronted with excessive closeness to outside activities and lots of
people.  Of course this is measured by extroversion/introversion.
My impression is that many churches are totally blind to this fact
create environments that 'scare away' many who are naturally introverted
(there are many introverted characters in the Bible
quite introverted in preference
column2: and find the 'pressure' by many churches

column1: to participate
column2: to meet together in large groups

column1: uncomfortable.  Knowing what I know now

column2: there's nothing wrong with either extroversion or introversion

Maybe I should define extrovert/introvert more carefully since these words
are usually not used correctly in our culture.  The extrovert/introvert
scale is a measure of how a person is energized.  The following is
excerpted from my summary:
1.  Energizing - How a person is energized:
Extroversion (E)- Preference for drawing energy from the outside
world of people
Introversion (I)- Preference for drawing energy from one's internal
world of ideas
Hopefully this will elicit further discussion as to how churches can
structure themselves to meet the real needs of the people who comprise
the Body of Christ
column2: instead of trying to change people's personalities

Compartment syndrome occurs when swelling happens in a ""compartment""
bounded by fascia.  The pressure rises in the compartment and blood
supply and nerves are compromised.  The treatment is to open the
compartment surgically.  THe most common places for compartment
syndromes are the forearm and calf.  It is an emergency
if the pressure is not relieved

Standard colormaps were spec'd with the intention that window managers
would make them available. This doesn't mean that every window manager
author in the world immediately dropped everything they were doing and
implemented this at top priority.
The ESGE server we ship makes the XA_RGB_BEST_MAP available at
startup. It doesn't wait for window managers to do it.
Does your hardware have only one CLUT? Since standard colormaps
typically devour all 256 entries
column2: there is no way it can avoid

column1: displacing the entire default colormap if your hardware has only one
CLUT.
I don't believe standard colormaps are intended to aboid possible
colormap flashing between clients using the default coilormap. Rather
colormap flashing will be avoided between two clients that use the
same standard colormap. An example would be two clients that need a
full color range would both use XA_RGB_BEST_MAP (or whatever it's
called under X11R5).
If you are trying to avoid colormap flashing with the default
colormap
column2: your best bet is to try to load all the colors you use into

column1: that colormap. If you can't do that
column2: then you'll get flashing on a one

column1: hw CLUT framebuffer.
Now if your window manager used the same standard colormap as your
client
column2: this flashing could also be avoided. Perhaps some window

column1: managers have command line options for selecting standard colormaps?

{Description of ""External Tank"" option for SSF redesign deleted}
Yo Ken
column2: let's keep on-top of things! Both the ""External Tank"" and

column1: Wingless Orbiter"" options have been deleted from the SSF redesign
options list. Today's (4/23) edition of the New York Times reports
that O'Connor told the panel that some redesign proposals have
been dropped
column2: such as using the ""giant external fuel tanks used

column1: in launching space shuttles
an existing space shuttle with its wings and tail removed.""
Currently
column2: there are three options being considered

column1: to the advisory panel meeting yesterday (and as reported in
today's Times).
Option ""A"" - Low Cost Modular Approach
This option is being studied by a team from MSFC. {As an aside
there are SSF redesign teams at MSFC
the SRT (Station Redesign Team) in Crystal City. Both LeRC and
Reston folks are also on-site at these locations
teams with their redesign activities.} Key features of this
option are:
-  Uses ""Bus-1""
column2: a modular bus developed by Lockheed that's

column1: qualified for STS and ELV's. The bus provides propulsion
Communications
for the Air Force.
-  A ""Power Station Capability"" is obtained in 3 Shuttle Flights.
SSF Solar arrays are used to provide 20 kW of power. The vehicle
flies in an ""arrow mode"" to optimize the microgravity environment.
Shuttle/Spacelab missions would utilize the vehilce as a power
source for 30 day missions.
-  Human tended capability (as opposed to the old SSF sexist term
of man-tended capability) is achieved by the addition of the
US Common module. This is a modified version of the existing
SSF Lab module (docking ports are added for the International
Partners' labs
column2: taking the place of the nodes on SSF). The

column1: Shuttle can be docked to the station for 60 day missions.
The Orbiter would provide crew habitability & EVA capability.
-  International Human Tended. Add the NASDA & ESA modules
add another 20 kW of power
-  Permanent Human Presence Capability. Add a 3rd power module
the U.S. habitation module
Vehicle).
Option ""B"" - Space Station Freedom Derived
The Option ""B"" team is based at LaRC
column2: and is lead by Mike Griffin.

column1: This option looks alot like the existing SSF design
have all come to know and love :)
This option assumes a lightweight external tank is available for
use on all SSF assembly flights (so does option ""A""). Also
number of flights is computed for a 51.6 inclination orbit
for both options ""A"" and ""B"".
The build-up occurs in six phases:
-  Initial Research Capability reached after 3 flights. Power
is transferred from the vehicle to the Orbiter/Spacelab
it visits.
-  Man-Tended Capability (Griffin has not yet adopted non-sexist
language) is achieved after 8 flights. The U.S. Lab is
deployed
column2: and 1 solar power module provides 20 kW of power.

column1: -  Permanent Human Presence Capability occurs after 10 flights
keeping one Orbiter on-orbit to use as an ACRV (so sometimes
there would be two Orbiters on-orbit - the ACRV
second one that comes up for Logistics & Re-supply).
-  A ""Two Fault Tolerance Capability"" is achieved after 14 flights
with the addition of a 2nd power module
control system radiator
-  After 20 flights
column2: the Internationals are on-board. More power

column1: the Habitation module
column2: and an ACRV are added to finish the

column1: assembly in 24 flights.
Most of the systems currently on SSF are used as-is in this option
with the exception of the data management system
changes."

column2: running from (say) the viscosity of a

column2: down to (say) that of a room-temperature

column1: 5-weight at 20C
Oils that are designed for operation in `normal' temperatures just have
a weight specification.  Oils that are designed for operation in exceedingly
cold temperatures have a `W' tacked on the end
column2: so in winter in a cold

column1: place
column2: you'd stick 10W in your car in the winter and 40 in it in the summer

column1: to approximate the appropriate viscosity throughout the year.
Modern multi-viscosity oils change viscosity much less with temperature.
As a result
column2: their viscosity graphs cross over several curves.  A multi-vis

column1: specification pegs the curve at two temperatures
temperature and a `cold' one (though I can't remember the numbers...).
In any event
column2: the weights do indicate a significant difference.  Remember

column1: that your engine is temperature-regulated (by the thermostat and
radiator or air fins) most of the time -- unless you overheat it or
something.
Any weight of oil is better than no oil
oil.  Thin oil won't (in general) lubricate as well at temperature
thicker oil will (like a 20W50) will lubricate better at temperature

While I agree with most of Jon says (I deleted those parts
have serious reservations about this advice.  Maintaining a `just
friends' level of relationship is much easier said than done.  People
usually end up getting hurt.  This is especially likely to happen when
they start off with feelings of attraction.
When people feel attracted those feelings can cloud their judgement.
I've had the experience of going quickly from believing that I shouldn't
date non-Christians to believing that dating this man would be okay to
believing that premarital sex is fine when people really love each
other.  When the relationship ended my beliefs immediately returned to
their original state.
This is an especially extreme case because I was young and away from home
and fellowship.  I don't think it would work exactly this way for most
people.  However
column2: it's important not to underestimate the power of

column1: feelings of attraction.  "

693|"Greetings fellow motorcycle roadracing enthusiasts!
BACKGROUND
The racing listserver (boogie.EBay.sun.com) contains discussions
devoted to racing and racing-related topics. This is a pretty broad
interest group. Individuals have a variety of backgrounds: motojournalism
roadracing from the perspective of pit crew and racers
motosports enthusiasts.
The size of the list grows weekly. We are currently at a little
over one hundred and eighty-five members
New Zealand
Finland
The list was formed (October 1991) in response to a perceived need
to both provide technical discussion of riding at the edge of
performance (roadracing) and to improve on the very low signal-to-noise
ratio found in rec.motorcycles. Anyone is free to join.
Discussion is necessarily limited by the rules of the list to
issues related to racing motorcycles and is to be ""flame-free"".
HOW TO GET THE DAILY DISTRIBUTION
You are welcome to subscribe. To subscribe send your request to:
race-request@boogie.EBay.Sun.COM
Traffic currently runs between five and twenty-five messages per day
(depending on the topic).
NB: Please do _not_ send your subscription request to the
list directly.
After you have contacted the list administrator
an RSVP request. Please respond to this request in a timely manner
so that you can be added to the list. The request is generated in
order to insure that there is a valid mail pathway to your site.
Upon receipt of your RSVP
column2: you will be added to either the daily

column1: or digest distribution (as per your initial request).
HOW TO GET THE DIGEST DISTRIBUTION
It is possible to receive the list in 'digest'ed form (ie. a
single email message). The RoadRacing Digest is mailed out
whenever it contains enough interesting content. Given the
frequency of postings this appears to be about every other
day.
Should you wish to receive the list via digest (once every
30-40K or so)
column2: please send a subscription request to:

column1: digest-request@boogie.EBay.Sun.COM
HOW TO POST TO THE LIST
This is an open forum. To post an article to the list
race@boogie.EBay.Sun.COM
Depending on how mail is set up at your site you may or may
not see the mail that you have posted. If you want to see it
(though this isn't necessarily a guarantee that it went out)
you can include a ""metoo"" line in your .mailrc file (on UNIX
based mail systems).
BOUNCES
Because I haven't had the time (or the inclination to replace
the list distribution mechanism) we still have a problem with
bounces returning to the poster of a message. Occasionally
sites or users go off-line (either leaving their place of
employment prematurely or hardware problems) and you will receive
bounces from the race list. Check the headers carefully
if you find that the bounce originated at Sun (from whence I
administer this list) contact me through my administration
hat (race-request@boogie.EBay.sun.com). If not
OTHER LISTS
Two-strokes:     2strokes@microunity.com
Harleys:         harley-request@thinkage.on.ca
or  uunet!watmath!thinkage!harley-request
European bikes:  majordomo@onion.rain.com
(in body of message write: subscribe euro-moto)
thanks
Rich (race list administrator)
rich@boogie.EBay.Sun.COM"

It clearly depends on the type of questions you are asking but in many
cases it will do fine. The critical information from the neuron is in
the firing frequency (maximum about 100 action potentials per
seconds)
column2: and not in the amplitude of the signal or in details of the

column1: signal shape. So the resolution of about 0.4 % you get with an 8 bit
convertor is more then sufficient.
AC coupling does not have to be a problem either
you are not interested in the DC level. My pre amplifier is AC coupled
also. The critical point is the lowest frequency that will pass. If
the cutoff point is to high
column2: the action potentials will be slightly

column1: distorted. But even that normally does not matter since it is the
occurrence of the spike that is important.

751|"This is the third and final call for votes for the creation of the
newsgroup misc.health.diabetes.  A mass acknowledgement of valid votes
received as of April 19th 14:00 GMT appears at the end of this
posting.  Please check the list to be sure that your vote has been
registered.  Read the instructions for voting carefully and follow
them precisely to be certain that you place a proper vote.
Instructions for voting:
To place a vote FOR the creation of misc.health.diabetes
email message to yes@sun6850.nrl.navy.mil
To place a vote AGAINST creation of misc.health.diabetes
email message to no@sun6850.nrl.navy.mil
The contents of the message should contain the line ""I vote
for/against misc.health.diabetes as proposed"".  Email messages sent to
the above addresses must constitute unambiguous and unconditional
votes for/against newsgroup creation as proposed.  Conditional votes
will not be accepted.  Only votes emailed to the above addresses will
be counted; mailed replies to this posting will be returned.  In the
event that more than one vote is placed by an individual
most recent vote will be counted.
Voting will continue until 23:59 GMT
Votes will not be accepted after this date.
Any administrative inquiries pertaining to this CFV may be made by
email to swkirch@sun6850.nrl.navy.mil
The proposed charter appears below.
Charter:
misc.health.diabetes                            unmoderated
1.   The purpose of misc.health.diabetes is to provide a forum for the
discussion of issues pertaining to diabetes management
activities
medical breakthroughs
column2: etc.  This group addresses the issues of

column1: management of both Type I (insulin dependent) and Type II (non-insulin
dependent) diabetes.  Both technical discussions and general support
discussions relevant to diabetes are welcome.
2.   Postings to misc.heath.diabetes are intended to be for discussion
purposes only
column2: and are in no way to be construed as medical advice.

column1: Diabetes is a serious medical condition requiring direct supervision
by a primary health care physician.
-----(end of charter)-----

I am glad that I am not an atheist.  It seems tragic that some people
choose a meaningless existence.  How terrible to go on living only
because one fears death more than life.  I feel so sorry for Eric and
yet any attempts to share my joy in life with him would be considered as
further evidence of the infectious nature of Christianity.
As a Christian I am free to be a human person.  I think
and create.  I will live forever with God.
Christ is not a kind of drug.  Drugs are a replacement for Christ.
Those who have an empty spot in the God-shaped hole in their hearts must
do something to ease the pain.  This is why the most effective
substance-abuse recovery programs involve meeting peoples' spiritual
needs.
Thank you
column2: Eric for your post.  It has helped me to appreciate how much

column1: God has blessed me.  I hope that you will someday have a more joy-filled
and abundant life."
763|"Thanks to all those people who recommended Workspace managers for
Windows 3.1.  I found 3 shareware Workspace Managers
MS-WINDOWS archive (monu6.cc.monash.edu.au)
sites in the U.S.  The three I found were:
1. WORKSPACES 1.10 (wspace.zip)
This was the smallest and simplest
of the workspace managers that I found.  It is very easy to use.
It displays a small window
button for configuration purposes.  One annoying feature was the
title window that is first presented when it is run - you must press
a key (not a mouse button!) for the thing to go away.  Also
have been nice if there was an ""ALWAYS ON TOP"" setting for the little
window containing the workspace buttons.  Maybe some user-specified
strings on the buttons instead of the numbers one to six might be
a nice feature.  The simplicity and ease of use of this workspace
manager makes it an attractive package.
2. WORKSHIFT 1.6 (wrksft16.zip)
While this workspace manager offered a
few features that WORKSPACES 1.10 lacked
to set things up.  With WORKSPACES 1.10
is initially empty.  With WORKSHIFT 1.6
of how you want each of your workspaces to look like - i.e. what
applications they contain.  Also
column2: the main window is quite large

column1: but this does allow you to have a small view of what is in each workspace.
With WORKSPACES 1.10
column2: there was no facility for viewing what was in

column1: a workspace without switching to it.  WORKSHIFT 1.6 provides this
viewing functionality which is quite useful.
3. BIGDESK 2.30 and BACKMENU (backdesk.zip)
This is an interesting package
a few other goodies as well as a workspace manager.  Other goodies
include ""Backmenu""
column2: which provides a pop-up root menu when you

column1: press a certain mouse button - just like in X-Windows.  The menu
is totally configurable
column2: offering unlimited depth of cascading menus

column1: which is provides quite handy access to applications.  You could
say it is a menu-based alternative to the program manager.  Also
bundled in ""backdesk.zip"" is a program called ""WRUN""
you to run windows applications from a DOS shell under WINDOWS
instead of using the File Manager to run applications.
The actual workspace manager is called BIGDESK 2.30.  BIGDESK works quite
differently to the other two workspace managers in that it
doesn't provide a certain number of disjoint and separate workspaces.
In fact
column2: it basically enlarges your desktop by a configurable amount

column1: and you choose which region of the desktop you want your screen to
focus in on.  This means you can have windows overlapping between different
viewing regions
column2: unlike the first two workspace managers in which

column1: each workspace was isolated from the other one.  The BIGDESK control window
allows to to move windows around your enlarged desktop.  Basically
the control window provides a small scale view of your viewing area

one
column2: the Sox would have lost in nine.

column2: providing the speed to go from first

column1: to third when...

column2: getting the run home with a sac fly.  Not much of

column1: a help

column1: way from first!  (Hill's lack of defense helped.)

column1: runs.  Did Melvin contribute more than Cooper?  Cooper provided the

column2: and moved the tying run to third base with

column1: only one out!

Good I had a bad feeling about this problem because of a special case
with no solution that worried me.
Four coplanar points in the shape of a square have no unique sphere
that they are on the surface of.
Similarly 4 colinear point have no finite sized sphere that they are on the
surface of.
These algorithms being geometrical designed rather than algebraically design
meet these problems neatly.
When determining which plane the 3 points are on if they are colinear
the algorithm should afil or return infinite R.
When intersecting the two lines there are 2 possibilities
they are the same line  (the 4 points were on a planar circle)
they are different lines but parallel. There is a sphere of in radius.
This last case can be achieved with 3 colinier points and any 4th point
by taking the 4th point and pairs of the first 3 parallel lines will be produced
it can also be achieved by
If all 4 points are coplanar but are not on one circle.
It seems to me that the algorithm only fails when the 4 points are coplanar.
The algorithm always fails when the points are coplanar.
(4 points being colinear => coplanar)
Testing if the 4th point is coplanar when the plane of the first 3 points
has been found is trivial.

in the subject line so that my mail filter will put it in the correct
mail folder.
Please DO NOT ask me questions that are not answered in the FAQ.  I do not
have time to respond to these individually.  Instead
to the net
column2: and send me the question and answer together when you get it.

column1: Frequently Asked Questions About X on Intel-based Unix (with answers)
I) What options do I have for X software on my Intel-based Unix system?
1. Free options
The BEST option is XFree86
column2: which is an enhanced version of X386 1.2.

column1: Any other version of X386 will have slower performance
be more difficult to compile.  Information on how to obtain XFree86
is listed below.
X386 is the port of the X11 server to System V/386 that was
done by Thomas Roell (roell@sgcs.com).
It supports a wide variety of SVGA boards.
There are 2 major free versions: X386 1.1 is based on X11R4
X386 1.2 is included in MIT's X11R5 distribution (ie. you
don't need to patch it into the MIT source any more).
X386 1.3 is the current commercial offering from SGCS (see below).
2. Commercial options
1) Metro Link
2213 W. McNab Road
Pompano Beach
email: sales@metrolink.com
Summary: OS:    QNX

HW:    EGA
S3

Xv Video Extension
2) SGCS (Snitily Graphics Consulting Services)
894 Brookgrove Lane
Cupertino
email: info@sgcs.com  or ...!mips!zok!info
Summary: OS: SVR3.2
HW: 8514/A (ATI Ultra)
Other: Motif
3) Consensys Corporation
1301 Pat Booker Rd.
Universal City
email: info@consensys.com

Other: MoOLIT

Santa Cruz

WD90C31
Compatabilty Guide for actual card vendors).
Other: Motif

p.o. box 14171
Columbus
email: sales@x4coher.com
Summary: OS: Coherent 4.0.1r72 or greater
HW: works with any VESA compliant video
NOTE: Other commercial vendors (including OS vendors describing
bundled software) are welcome to submit summary information
summary information such as the above.
II) What is XFree86 and where do I get it?
3. What is XFree86?
XFree86 is an enhanced version of X386 1.2
X11R5.  This release consists of many bug fixes
other enhancements.  Here are the highlights of the enhancements:
1) The SpeedUp package from Glenn Lai is an integral part of XFree86
selectable at run-time via the Xconfig file.  Some SpeedUps require
an ET4000 based SVGA
column2: and others require a virtual screen width of

column1: 1024.  The SpeedUps suitable to the configuration are selected by
default.  With a high-quality ET4000 board (VRAM)
up to 40% improvement of the xStones benchmark over X386 1.2.
2) The fX386 packages from Jim Tsillas are included as the default
operating mode if SpeedUp is not selected.  This mode is now
equivalent in performance to X386 1.1b (X11R4)
20% faster than X386 1.2.
3) Support for LOCALCONN
or both.  This support is for both SVR3.2 and SVR4.  For SVR4.0.4
with the 'Advanced Compatibility Package'
SCO XSight/ODT clients are supported.
4) Drivers for ATI and Trident TVGA8900C and TVGA9000 SVGA chipsets.
Refer to the files README.ati and README.trident for details about
the ATI and Trident drivers.
5) Support for compressed bitmap fonts has been added (Thomas Eberhardt's
code from the contrib directory on export.lcs.mit.edu).
6) Type1 Font code from MIT contrib tape has been included
compile-time selectable.  There are contributed Type1 fonts in the
contrib directory on export.lcs.mit.edu.
7) New configuration method which allows the server's drivers and font
renderers to be reconfigured from both source and binary
distributions.
8) Integrated support for 386BSD
9) A monochrome version of the server which will run on generic VGA
cards is now included.
The following key features were added with the release of XFree86 1.2
(they were not in XFree86 1.1):
1) The monochrome server has been enhanced to do bank-switching of
available SVGA memory to allow virtual screens up to 1600x1200
(see the X386(1) manual page for more information).
2) Support for the Hercules mono card has been added to the
monochrome server
column2: and with it the ability to support a ""two

column1: headed"" server - one VGA
column2: and one Hercules.  So far this has only

column1: been tested on SVR4 (it is also reported to work under Linux).
3) SVR3 shared libraries
4) Support for SVR4.2 (There are some special considerations to
consider
column2: due to new USL bugs; see the README.SVR4 file for

column1: more information.)
5) Support for PS/2 mice
versions of these devices were not previously compatible).
6) A new tutorial on how to develop correct video card and monitor
timing data
column2: written by Eric Raymond (derived from previous

column1: documentation and a lot of experimentation).
7) Greatly improved support for international keyboards
implementation of the Compose key functionality found on many
vendor servers (see the X386keybd(1) manual page for more
information).
8) The accuracy with which the server detects SVGA pixel clocks has
been improved
column2: and the timings are now stored at accuracies of

column1: 0.1 MHz.  Users may want to consider removing an existing Clocks
line from their Xconfig file and re-probing using the new server.
9) Many enhancements in error handling and parsing of the Xconfig
configuration file.  Error messages are much more informative
and intuitive
column2: and more validation is done.  There are many new

column1: options that can be enabled in the Xconfig file (see the X386(1)
manual page for more information on the format of this file).
Plus a number of other small things.  Refer to the CHANGELOG file
in the source distribution for full details.
Also included are a tutorial on monitor timing by Eric Raymond
current X386 mode database and a sample xdm configuration by David Wexelblat.
4. What OSs are supported?
XFree86 supports:
SVR4.2: Consensys V4.2
SVR4.0: Microport
SVR3: ISC 2.2 & 3.0
Linux
BSD/386 is not supported
column2: but it should work. The most active

column1: BSD/386 person is Greg Lehey <grog@lemis.de>.
Note that Esix 3.2D and SCO are not supported yet
but anyone should feel free to submit patches.
If you are interested in tackling this
xfree86@physics.su.oz.au
5. What video hardware is supported?
At this time
column2: XFree86 1.2 supports the following SVGA chipsets:

column1: Tseng ET4000
Tseng ET3000
Paradise PVGA1
Western Digital WD90C00
the PVGA1
Genoa GVGA
Trident TVGA8900C
All of the above are supported in both 256 color and monochrome modes
with the exception of the ATI chipsets
256 color mode.
The monochrome server also supports generic VGA cards
video memory in a single bank
column2: and the Hercules card.  On the
only 64k of video memory is supported for the monochrome

column1: server
column2: and the GVGA has not been tested with more than 64k.

column1: It appears that some of the SVGA card manufacturers are going to
non-traditional mechanisms for selecting pixel-clock frequencies.  To
avoid having to modify the server to accommodate these schemes XFree86
1.2 adds support for using an external program to select the pixel
clock.  This allows programs to be written as new mechanisms are
discovered.  Refer to the README.clkprog file for information on how
these programs work
column2: if you need to write one.  If you do develop such

column1: a program
column2: the XFree86 team would be interested in including it with

column1: future XFree86 releases.
If you are purchasing new hardware for the purpose of using XFree86
it is suggested that you purchase an ET4000-based board such as the
Orchid ProDesigner IIs.  Avoid recent Diamond boards; XFree86 will not
work with them
column2: because Diamond won't provide programming details.

column1: In fact
column2: the XFree86 project is actively not supporting new Diamond

column1: products
column2: as long as such policies remain in effect.  Contributions

column1: of code will NOT be accepted (because of the potential liabilities).
If you would like to see this change
Some people have asked if XFree86 would work with local bus or EISA
video cards. Theoretically
column2: the means of communication between the

column1: CPU and the video card is irrelevant to Xfree86 compatibility. It
could be ISA
column3: or local bus.  What should matter is the chipset

column1: on the video card.  Unfortunately
column2: the developers don't have a lot

column1: of access to EISA or VLB machines
column2: so this is largely an untested

column1: theory.  However
column2: we have yet to see any reports of things not

column1: working on one of these buses and we have several reports of Xfree86
working fine on them.
6. What about accelerated boards?
At this time
column2: there is no support in XFree86 for accelerated boards

column1: like the S3
in commercial products from SGCS and MetroLink (for SVR3 and SVR4).
An S3 server is available for 386BSD and Linux.  Contact
<hasty@netcom.com> for 386BSD or <jon@robots.ox.ac.uk> for Linux.
A beta 8514/A server is available for Linux. Contact <martin@cs.unc.edu>
or <jon@robots.ox.ac.uk>. Note: these servers are NOT part of XFree86.
7. Why doesn't XFree86 support 16-color VGA modes?
The reason that this is not supported is the way VGA implements the
16-color modes.  In 256-color modes
column2: each byte of frame buffer memory

column1: contains 1 pixel.  But the 16-color modes are implemented as bit-
planes.  Each byte of frame- buffer memory contains 1 bit from each
of each of 8 pixels
column2: and there are four such planes.  The MIT frame-

column1: buffer code is not designed to deal with this.  If VGA handled
16-color modes by packing 2 4-bit pixels into each byte
could be modified to support this (or it already may; I'm not sure).
But for the VGA way of doing things
implementation is required.  Some beta testers are looking into this
but nothing is yet available from the project.
8. What other hardware or software requirements are there?
Obviously
column2: a supported SVGA board and OS are required.  To run

column1: X efficiently
column2: 12-16MB of memory should be considered a minimum.

column1: The various binary releases take 10-40MB of disk space
on the OS (e.g. whether or not it supports shared libraries).
To build from sources
column2: at least 80MB of free disk space will

column1: be required
column2: although 120MB should be considered a comfortable

column1: lower bound.
9. Where can I get source for XFree86?
Source patches for the current version (1.2
from MIT)
column2: are available via anonymous FTP from:

column1: export.lcs.mit.edu (under /contrib/XFree86)
ftp.physics.su.oz.au (under /XFree86)
ftp.win.tue.nl (under /pub/XFree86)
(For the rest of this FAQ
Refer to the README file under the specified directory for information
on which files you need to get to build your distribution.
10. Where can I get binaries for XFree86?
Binaries are available via anonymous FTP from:
ftp.physics.su.oz.au		- SVR4 binaries
under /XFree86/SVR4
ftp.win.tue.nl			- SVR4 binaries
under /pub/XFree86/SVR4
ferkel.ucsb.edu			- SVR4 binaries
under /pub/SVR4/XFree86
stasi.bradley.edu		- SVR4 binaries
under /pub/XFree86/SVR4
blancmange.ma.utexas.edu	- SVR3 (ISC) binaries
under /pub/ISC
ftp.prz.tu-berlin.de            - SVR3 (ISC) binaries
under /pub/pc/isc/XFree86
tsx-11.mit.edu			- Linux binaries
under /pub/linux/packages/X11
agate.berkeley.edu		- 386BSD binaries
under /pub/386BSD/0.1-ports/XFree86
ftp.cs.uwm.edu			- Mach binaries
under /i386
Ensure that you are getting XFree86 1.2 - some of these sites may
archive older releases as well.  Each binary distribution will
contain a README file that describes what files you need to take
from the archive
column2: and which compile-time option selections were

column1: made when building the distribution.
IV) What general things should I know about running XFree86?
11. Installation directories
The top-level installation directory is specified by the ProjectRoot
(/usr/X386
column2: by default) variable in config/site.def. Binaries

column1: files
This can be changed when rebuilding from sources
via symbolic links for those OSs that support them. This directory is
nonstandard
column2: and was chosen this way to allow XFree86 to be installed

column1: alongside a commercial/vendor-supplied X implementation.
12. Configuration files
The XFree86 server reads a configuration file (""Xconfig"") on startup.
The search path
column2: contents and syntax for this file are documented in

column1: the server manpage
column2: which should be consulted before asking questions.

column1: 13. Determining VGA dot clocks and monitor modes
David E Wexelblat (dwex@mtgzfs3.att.com) maintains a database of known
clock settings for VGA cards and monitor settings.
The database is installed in /usr/X386/lib/X11/etc/modeDB.txt
is in the source tree under mit/server/ddx/x386/etc. This database is
also available from him (for the latest copy)
export.lcs.mit.edu in ~/contrib/X386.modeDB.Z
occasionally.  Obtain a copy of this database.  It just might have the
settings you need.  If you create new settings
David for inclusion in the database.
If this doesn't help you
with XFree86 contains tutorials on how to come up with these timings.
It may be helpful to start with settings that almost work
this description to get them right.  When you do
to David Wexelblat for inclusion in the database.
NOTE: The old 'clock.exe' program is not supported any more
is completely unnecessary.  If you need to determine dot
clock values for a new board
your Xconfig file (if present)
server will probe for clocks itself and print them out.
You can use these values to put a 'Clocks' line into your
Xconfig file
starting the server in the future.
14. Rebuilding/reconfiguring the server from the link kit
If you have installed the server Binary Link Kit
reconfigure the drivers and font renderers in the server.  This is
fully explained in the README file that is available with the link kit.
V) What OS-specific things should I know about running XFree86?
First of all
column2: the server must be installed suid-root (mode 4755).

column1: 15. SVR4
Why won't my xterm run properly?
If your kernel is not built with the consem module
CONSEM=no in you environment. Otherwise xterm won't run.
csh users should use 'setenv CONSEM no'
The Esix console driver patch 403019 is known to cause keymapping
problems with XFree86.  It recommended that this patch not be
installed.  Alternatively they keymap can be fixed with xmodmap.
16. SVR3
Make sure you look at $FTP/README.ISC
column2: if that's what you are running.

column1: Make sure you look at $FTP/README.386BSD.
Also
column2: a separate 386BSD FAQ is maintained by Richard Murphey

column1: <Rich@Rice.edu>.  The latest version should be available in the
file XFree86-1.2-386BSD-FAQ at the following ftp sites:
agate.berkeley.edu:/pub/386BSD/0.1-ports/XFree86-1.2
wuarchive.wustl.edu:/mirrors4/386bsd/0.1-ports/XFree86-1.2
grasp1.univ-lyon1.fr:pub/386BSD/0.1-ports/XFree86-1.2
18. Linux
You must be running Linux 0.97pl4 or greater
jump libraries installed.
Make sure the binaries X386
column3: xload and xterm are setuid root.

column1: If your kernel doesn't have TCP support compiled in
run the server as ""X -pn"". The default startup configuration assumes
that TCP is not available. If it is
/usr/X386/bin/startx and /usr/X386/lib/X11/xdm/Xservers
-pn argument to X386.
Make sure /dev/console is either a link to /dev/tty0 or has the major
number 4
column2: minor number 0. Also note that if /dev/console is not

column1: owned by the user running X
column2: then xconsole and xterm will not permit

column1: console output redirection. Xdm will properly change the owner
startx won't.
When running xdm from rc.local
column2: you will need to provide it with

column1: a tty
For more detailed information
column2: please read the file README present

column1: with the distribution on tsx-11.mit.edu.
19. Mach
Make sure you look at $FTP/README.Mach.
VI) What things should I know for building XFree86 from source?
This section has been removed from the FAQ
fully explained in $FTP/README and the OS-specific READMEs.
Please look at those files for information on building XFree86.
VII) Is there anything special about building clients with XFree86?
20. BSD compatibility library
A lot of clients make use of BSD functions like bcopy()
The default configuration files are set up to link with libXbsd.a
which contains emulation for bcopy()
seed(). A better way of providing the 'b' functions is to include
<X11/Xfuncs.h> in source files that call them.  Xfuncs.h provides macro
definitions for these in terms of the SYSV 'mem' functions.  If you are
linking with a vendor supplied library which calls some of these
functions
column2: then you should link with libXbsd.a

column1: 21. ANSICCOPTIONS
This is something that was added to allow a developer to get rid of the
ANSI-ness defined in the default CCOPTIONS without having to rewrite
the entire CCOPTIONS line.  For example
something like
CCOPTIONS=""-ansi -O2 -fwritable-strings""
and to get rid of the ANSI-ness
column2: the developer would have to put

column1: CCOPTIONS=""-O2 -fwritable-strings""
in his Imakefile.  With this change
column2: you would see a default of

column1: ANSICCOPTIONS=""-ansi""
CCOPTIONS=""-O2 -fwritable-strings""
and all the developer would have to put in the Imakefile is:
ANSICCOPTIONS=
to get rid of the ANSI-ness (many X clients will die a horrible death
with -ansi).  The effect is even more dramatic in practice
CCOPTIONS is actually quite complex.  The other issue is that one must
add 'ANSICCOPTIONS=$(ANSICCOPTIONS)' to a PassCDebugFlags definition.
XFree86 Contact Information
Ongoing development planning and support is coordinated by the XFree86
Core Team.  At this time the Core Team consists of:
The original ""gang of four"":

Those supporting non-SYSV operating systems:
Robert Baron <Robert.Baron@ernst.mach.cs.cmu.edu> [Mach]
Rich Murphey <Rich@Rice.edu> [386BSD]
Orest Zborowski <obz@kodak.com> [Linux]
e-mail sent to <xfree86@physics.su.oz.au> will reach all of the core team.
Thanks to all the people who already sent me corrections or additions
especially David Wexelblat (one of the major contributors of updates)."

This is not good advice.  A couple of years I was involved in a low-speed
getoff in which I landed on my back on the pavement.  My head (helmeted)
hit the pavement with a ""clunk""
column2: leaving a couple of dings and chips in the

column1: paint at the point of impact
column2: but no other visible damage.  I called the

column1: helmet manufacturer and inquired about damage.  They said that the way a
fiberglass shell works is to first give
This is the way fiberglass serves to spread the force of the impact over a
wider area.  After the fiberglass has done its thing
liner takes care of absorbing (hopefully) the remaining impact force.
They told me that the second stage of fiberglass functionality (delamination
of the glass/resin layers) can occur with NO visible signs
outside of the helmet.  They suggested that I send them the helmet and they
would inspect it (including X-raying).  I did so.  They sent back the helmet
with a letter stating that that they could find no damage that would
compromise the ability of the helmet to provide maximum protection.
(I suspect that this letter would eliminate their being able to claim
prior damage to the helmet in the event I were to sue them.)
The bottom line
column3: is that it appears that a helmets integrity

column1: can be compromised with no visible signs.  The only way to know for sure
is to send it back and have it inspected.  Note that some helmet
manufacturers provide inspections services and some do not.  Another point
to consider when purchasing a lid.

Speed is a quantifiable measure resulting from a set of methods that
will result in the same value measured no matter the reference.  A
bullet with zero velocity sitting on a table on a train moving 60mph
will be moving at a speed of
(a) 0mph to someone on the train.
(b) 60mph to someone stationary next to the train.
The reference frame makes the speed relative.  But what's interesting
here is that every person on the train will see a stationary bullet.

column3: limit you to generating dots at 300 per inch.

column1: The method of depositing and fusing toner of a laster printer
results in much less spread than ink drop technology.
It doesn't take much investigation to see that the mechanical and
electronic complement of a laser printer is more complex than
inexpensive ink jet printers.  Recall also that laser printers
offer a much higher throughput:  10 ppm for a laser versus about 1
ppm for an ink jet printer.
Something else to think about is the cost of consumables over the
life of the printer.  A 3000 page yield toner cartridge is about
$US 75-80 at discount while HP high capacity (~500-1000 page yield)
cartridges are about $US 22 at discount.  It could be that over the
life cycle of the printer that consumables for laser printers are
less than ink jet printers.  It is getting progressively closer
between the two technologies.  Laser printers are usually desinged
for higher duty cycles in pages per month and longer product
replacement cycles.

string 1 bulbs
column2: because of the second string of bulbs in

column1: parallel with it.  That's why the use of the 10K 5W resistor
here to add extra current thru the blinker to make up for the
current shunted thru the second string while the blinker is glowing
and the second string is not glowing.  When the blinker goes open
this resistor has only a slight effect on the brightness of the
strings

one.  Caution

at full brightness
from the second string

column1: both strings in series

rockets as payloads.  Thiokol provided me with samples and data on
a reinforcement to solid motor grains for high accelerations.  Solid
motor propellants usually have a substantial percentage of
aluminum in the mix.  For example
column2: the Space Shuttle SRBs are 16 percent

column1: Aluminum.  The technique is to use a 'foamed aluminum' structure.
The structure looks like the inverse of a set of bubbles (an I suspect
some bubbling process is used to form it).  In other words
a bunch of bubbles in molten aluminum
you get.  It forms a strong network of effectively aluminum wires in
all directions.  The remaining solid fuel mix is infiltrated into
the voids
column2: and you get aluminum-reinforced solid propellant.  The

column1: foamed-aluminum makes up about 6 percent of the total propellant
so there is still aluminum particles in the bulk grain.  The major
improvement is the higher resistance to grain cracking
principal failure mode for solid propellant.

At Robert Gordon University
start of the course. The first two years consisted of five subjects:
Software Engineering (Pascal/C/UNIX)
assembler)
Communication Skills (How to pass interviews/intelligence tests and group
discussions e.g. How to survive a helicopter crash in the North Sea).
The third year (Industrial placement) was spent working for a computer company
for a year. The company could be anywhere in Europe (there was a special
Travel Allowance Scheme to cover the visiting costs of professors).
The fourth year included Operating Systems(C/Modula-2)
(C/8086 assembler)
column2: Real Time Laboratory (C/68000 assembler) and Computing

column1: Theory (LISP).  There were also Group Projects in 2nd and 4th Years
students worked in teams to select their own project or decide to work for an
outside company (the only disadvantage being that specifications would change
suddenly).
In the first four years
column2: there was a 50%:50% weighting between courseworks and

column1: exams for most subjects. However in the Honours year
30%:70% split between an Individual Project and final exams (no coursework
assessment) - are all Computer Science courses like this?
BTW - we started off with 22 students in our first year and were left with 8 by
Honours year. Also
column2: every course is tutored separately. Not easy trying

column1: to sleep when you are in 8 student class :-).
Cheers
Michael "

Sec. 2923.181.  (A)  ANY PERSON WHO ACQUIRED A MILITARY
WEAPON BEFORE THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THIS SECTION SHALL FILE A
WRITTEN APPLICATION FOR A LICENSE TO HAVE AND CARRY THE MILITARY

POLICE CHIEF OF THE MUNICIPAL CORPORATION WHERE THE APPLICANT
RESIDES OR HAS HIS PRINCIPAL PLACE OF BUSINESS.  THE APPLICATION

The third-party media adapters are usually cheaper (at least in Toronto) than

That's not true. Only the DECstation 5000/200 comes with a Thinwire
(BNC
all have a single 15-pin AUI Ethernet connector only. I distinctly
remembered this because when got the 5000/200 first and I thought all
of them are going to be Thinwire. I eventually had to go back and ordered
DESTAs (DEC's oversized version of an AUI-to-BNC adapter that MUST be used
with a transciever cable) for the rest of the stations.
My advise to the very original poster (Beverly?) is:
(1) If all you want is to create a LAN with two workstations and won't add
machines to it EVER
column2: go for Thinwire regardless of the media type. Going

column1: for UTP (unshielded twisted pair) wiring requires a concentrator which
means extra money and I believe these units come with at least 6 ports.
As for Thicknet
column2: it's a nightmare and cabling is expensive. Avoid it

column1: unless you have no choice (e.g. the two machines are two floors parts).
(2) On the Mac side
- one Thinwire media adapter (from Apple or third-party).
- MacX (make sure you get version 1.2; 1.1.7 won't run on System 7.1).
- MacTCP (which comes with MacX; if you get MacX v1.2
getting MacTCP v1.1.1 with it. Don't use earlier versions on a Centris).
- you may or may not need a 25ohm terminator depending on the
Thinwire media adapter. So just ask the sales if the adapter is
self-terminated or not.
- configure MacTCP to use ""Ethernet"".
(3) On the DECstation side
- for a Model 200
column2: you will only need a T-connector.

column1: - for Models 25
column5: you will need an AUI-to-BNC adapter.

column1: Get one that can be plugged in directly to the AUI port of the
DECstation. This way you save the cost of a transciever cable
(a 15-pin AUI male to a 15-pin AUI female cable).
- get a 25ohm terminator.
Your two-machine network will look like this:
DECstation                                        Centris
OR
DECstation                                        Centris
##    -> 25ohm terminator
T     -> T connector
---   -> Thinwire (RG58 coaxial cable)
{=}   -> AUI-to-BNC (i.e. Thick-to-Thin) adapter
[]    -> Thickwire media adapter (assuming self-terminated)
Andy"

I just put replaced the motherboard in a system and had similar questions.
My 2 cents worth:
The speaker connector should have two wires going to the speaker.
A speaker being a coil
column2: it's bidirectional and makes no difference

column1: which way you attach.
Turbo switch.   There are three wires to control how you want turbo
to become active- with the switch pushed in or the switch out.    I think
the middle wire is common.   Use an ohm meter to figure out which wire
connects with the common wire when the switch is pushed in
wires are connected when the switch is out.   Place the appropriate
two wires on the turbo berg connector of the motherboard.
LED's:   (Turbo and HD)  LED's are uni directional.  Depending which
way the wires are attached the LED will not light.  On my AMI motherboard
if the turbo switch wires are not attached to the berg connector on the
board
column2: the board will power up in default in Turbo mode.   If your motherboard

column1: is like that... just attace the LED wires to the board.  If the LED doesn't
light
column3: reverse the connectors and try again.   It should work.

column1: If it does
column2: then attach the turbo switch to the board.

column1: Hope this helps."

column1: In the September 1992 issue of THE TUFTS UNIVERSITY DIET AND NUTRITION
LETTER
column2: there is a three page article about artificial sweeteners.  What

column1: follows are those excerpts which deal specifically with Nutrasweet.
[Reproduced without permission]
The controversy [over aspartame] began six years ago in England
where a group of researchers found that aspartame
the tradename Nutrasweet
presumably
column2: the eating of more calories in the long run than if

column1: a person simply consumed sugar.  When researchers asked a group
of 95 people to drink plain water
sugared water
column2: they said that overall they felt hungriest after

column1: drinking the artificially sweetened beverage.
The study received widespread media attention and stirred a
good deal of concern among the artificial-sweetener-using public.
However
column2: its results were questionable at best

column1: did not go on to measure whether the increase in appetite did
actually translate into an increase in eating.  The two do not
necessarily go hand in hand.
In the years that followed
column2: more than a dozen studies examining

column1: the effect of aspartame on appetite -- and eating -- were conducted.
And after reviewing every one of them
Laboratory of the Study of Human Ingestive Behavior at Johns Hopkins
University
sweetened foods and drinks is not associated with any increase in
the amount of food eaten afterward.
One artificial sweetener that is not typically accused of causing
cancer is aspartame.  But it most certainly has been blamed for a
host of other ills.  Since its introduction in 1981
has received thousands of complaints accusing it of causing
everything from headaches to nausea to mood swings to anxiety.
Still
column2: years of careful scientific study conducted both before and

column1: after the sweetener's entering the market have failed to confirm
that it can bring about adverse health effects.  That's why the
Centers for Disease Control (the government agency charged with
monitoring public health)
Council on Scientific Affairs
column2: and the Food and Drug Administration

column1: have given aspartame
column2: one of the most studied food additives

column1: clean bill of health.
Granted
column2: the FDA has set forth an ""acceptable daily intake"" of

column1: 50 milligrams of aspartame per kilogram of body weight.  To exceed
the limit
column3: a 120-pound (55 kg.) woman would have to take

column1: in 2
column2: 750 milligrams of aspartame -- the amount in 15 cans of

column1: aspartame-sweetened soda pop
or 55 six-ounce servings of aspartame-containing hot cocoa
A 175-pound (80 kg.) man would have to consume some 4
of the sweetener -- the amount in 22 cans of soda pop or 32 cups
of yogurt -- to go over the limit.  [chart with aspartame content
of selected foods omitted]
Only one small group of people must be certain to stay away
from aspartame: those born with a rare metabolic disorder called
phenylketonuria
column2: or PKU.  The estimated one person in every 12

column1: to 15
column2: 000 who has it is unable to properly metabolize an essential

column1: amino acid in aspartame called phenylalanine.  Once a child
consumes it
column2: it builds up in the body and can ultimately cause

column1: such severe problems as mental retardation.  To help people with
PKU avoid the substance
column2: labels on cans of soda pop and other

column1: aspartame-sweetened foods must carry the warning ""Phenylketonurics:
Contains Phenylalanine.""

column2: it's a vertical wooden box with

Or
column2: at a slightly higher cost in electricity
column3: you can do what I do:  Use

column1: your oven.  (NOTE - I do this in an electric oven; some gas ovens may
not have a low enough setting).  Put food to be dried on cookie tins or
racks in the oven.  Set oven to 140 degrees (the lowest setting on my
oven - if yours goes down to 120 that's probably even better.)  Stick a
wooden spoon or something across the front corner of the oven and close
the door on the spoon so that it stays open about an inch - this allows
for airflow.  Leave the stuff in the oven for 6 to 8 hours; check it
often
column2: since this dries it much faster than the dehydrator.  If you are

column1: using cookie sheets instead of racks
