1055|"Archive-name: space/probe
Last-modified: $Date: 93/04/01 14:39:19 $
PLANETARY PROBES - HISTORICAL MISSIONS
This section was lightly adapted from an original posting by Larry Klaes
(klaes@verga.enet.dec.com)
Wiener (weemba@libra.wistar.upenn.edu) contributed the section on
Voyager
column2: and the section on Sakigake was obtained from ISAS material

column1: posted by Yoshiro Yamada (yamada@yscvax.ysc.go.jp).
US PLANETARY MISSIONS
MARINER (VENUS
MARINER 1
column2: the first U.S. attempt to send a spacecraft to Venus

column1: minutes after launch in 1962. The guidance instructions from the ground
stopped reaching the rocket due to a problem with its antenna
onboard computer took control. However
column2: there turned out to be a bug in

column1: the guidance software
column2: and the rocket promptly went off course

column1: Range Safety Officer destroyed it. Although the bug is sometimes claimed
to have been an incorrect FORTRAN DO statement
transcription error in which the bar (indicating smoothing) was omitted
from the expression ""R-dot-bar sub n"" (nth smoothed value of derivative
of radius). This error led the software to treat normal minor variations
of velocity as if they were serious
MARINER 2 became the first successful probe to flyby Venus in December

column2: and it returned information which confirmed that Venus is a

column1: very hot (800 degrees Fahrenheit
column2: now revised to 900 degrees F.) world

column1: with a cloud-covered atmosphere composed primarily of carbon dioxide
(sulfuric acid was later confirmed in 1978).
MARINER 3
shroud failed to eject as the craft was placed into interplanetary
space. Unable to collect the Sun's energy for power from its solar
panels
column2: the probe soon died when its batteries ran out and is now in

column1: solar orbit. It was intended for a Mars flyby with MARINER 4.
MARINER 4
took the first close-up images of the Martian surface (22 in all) as it
flew by the planet. The probe found a cratered world with an atmosphere
much thinner than previously thought. Many scientists concluded from
this preliminary scan that Mars was a ""dead"" world in both the
geological and biological sense.
MARINER 5 was sent to Venus in 1967. It reconfirmed the data on that
planet collected five years earlier by MARINER 2
that Venus' atmospheric pressure at its surface is at least 90 times
that of Earth's
of an ocean.
MARINER 6 and 7 were sent to Mars in 1969 and expanded upon the work
done by MARINER 4 four years earlier. However
the concept of Mars as a ""dead"" planet
measurements of MARINER 4.
MARINER 8 ended up in the Atlantic Ocean in 1971 when the rocket
launcher autopilot failed.
MARINER 9
orbit Mars in 1971. It returned information on the Red Planet that no
other probe had done before
column2: revealing huge volcanoes on the Martian

column1: surface
column2: as well as giant canyon systems

column1: flowed across the planet. The probe also took the first detailed closeup
images of Mars' two small moons
MARINER 10 used Venus as a gravity assist to Mercury in 1974. The probe
did return the first close-up images of the Venusian atmosphere in
ultraviolet
column2: revealing previously unseen details in the cloud cover

column1: plus the fact that the entire cloud system circles the planet in four
Earth days. MARINER 10 eventually made three flybys of Mercury from 1974
to 1975 before running out of attitude control gas. The probe revealed
Mercury as a heavily cratered world with a mass much greater than
thought. This would seem to indicate that Mercury has an iron core which
makes up 75 percent of the entire planet.
PIONEER (MOON
PIONEER 1 through 3 failed to meet their main objective - to photograph
the Moon close-up - but they did reach far enough into space to provide
new information on the area between Earth and the Moon
data on the Van Allen radiation belts circling Earth. All three craft
had failures with their rocket launchers. PIONEER 1 was launched on
October 11
PIONEER 4 was a Moon probe which missed the Moon and became the first
U.S. spacecraft to orbit the Sun in 1959. PIONEER 5 was originally
designed to flyby Venus
column2: but the mission was scaled down and it instead

column1: studied the interplanetary environment between Venus and Earth out to
36.2 million kilometers in 1960
through 9 were placed into solar orbit from 1965 to 1968: PIONEER 6
and 8 are still transmitting information at this time. PIONEER E (would
have been number 10) suffered a launch failure in 1969.
PIONEER 10 became the first spacecraft to flyby Jupiter in 1973. PIONEER
11 followed it in 1974
column2: and then went on to become the first probe to

column1: study Saturn in 1979. Both vehicles should continue to function through
1995 and are heading off into interstellar space
to do so.
PIONEER Venus 1 (1978) (also known as PIONEER Venus Orbiter
12) burned up in the Venusian atmosphere on October 8
the first radar studies of the planet's surface via probe. PIONEER Venus
2 (also known as PIONEER 13) sent four small probes into the atmosphere
in December of 1978. The main spacecraft bus burned up high in the
atmosphere
column2: while the four probes descended by parachute towards the

column1: surface. Though none were expected to survive to the surface
probe did make it and transmitted for 67.5 minutes on the ground before
its batteries failed.
RANGER (LUNAR LANDER AND IMPACT MISSIONS)
RANGER 1 and 2 were test probes for the RANGER lunar impact series. They
were meant for high Earth orbit testing in 1961
left them in useless low orbits which quickly decayed.
RANGER 3
instrument capsule on the surface of the Moon
launch caused the probe to miss the Moon and head into solar orbit.
RANGER 3 did try to take some images of the Moon as it flew by
camera was unfortunately aimed at deep space during the attempt.
RANGER 4
column4: had the same purpose as RANGER 3

column1: suffered technical problems enroute and crashed on the lunar farside
the first U.S. probe to reach the Moon
RANGER 5
all solar panel and battery power enroute and eventually missed the Moon
and drifted off into solar orbit.
RANGER 6 through 9 had more modified lunar missions: They were to send
back live images of the lunar surface as they headed towards an impact
with the Moon. RANGER 6 failed this objective in 1964 when its cameras
did not operate. RANGER 7 through 9 performed well
U.S. lunar probes to return thousands of lunar images through 1965.
LUNAR ORBITER (LUNAR SURFACE PHOTOGRAPHY)
LUNAR ORBITER 1 through 5 were designed to orbit the Moon and image
various sites being studied as landing areas for the manned APOLLO
missions of 1969-1972. The probes also contributed greatly to our
understanding of lunar surface features
All five probes of the series
essentially successful in their missions. They were the first U.S.
probes to orbit the Moon. All LOs were eventually crashed into the lunar
surface to avoid interference with the manned APOLLO missions.
SURVEYOR (LUNAR SOFT LANDERS)
The SURVEYOR series were designed primarily to see if an APOLLO lunar
module could land on the surface of the Moon without sinking into the
soil (before this time
column2: it was feared by some that the Moon was covered

column1: in great layers of dust
column2: which would not support a heavy landing

column1: vehicle). SURVEYOR was successful in proving that the lunar surface was
strong enough to hold up a spacecraft from 1966 to 1968.
Only SURVEYOR 2 and 4 were unsuccessful missions. The rest became the
first U.S. probes to soft land on the Moon
and scooping the soil for analysis. APOLLO 12 landed 600 feet from
SURVEYOR 3 in 1969 and returned parts of the craft to Earth. SURVEYOR 7
the last of the series
column2: was a purely scientific mission which explored

column1: the Tycho crater region in 1968.
VIKING (MARS ORBITERS AND LANDERS)
VIKING 1 was launched from Cape Canaveral
a TITAN 3E-CENTAUR D1 rocket. The probe went into Martian orbit on June

column3: and the lander set down on the western slopes of Chryse

column1: Planitia on July 20
column2: 1976. It soon began its programmed search for

column1: Martian micro-organisms (there is still debate as to whether the probes
found life there or not)
column2: and sent back incredible color panoramas of

column1: its surroundings. One thing scientists learned was that Mars' sky was
pinkish in color
column2: not dark blue as they originally thought (the sky is

column1: pink due to sunlight reflecting off the reddish dust particles in the
thin atmosphere). The lander set down among a field of red sand and
boulders stretching out as far as its cameras could image.
The VIKING 1 orbiter kept functioning until August 7
out of attitude-control propellant. The lander was switched into a
weather-reporting mode
column2: where it had been hoped it would keep

column1: functioning through 1994; but after November 13
had been sent to the lander accidentally telling it to shut down until
further orders. Communication was never regained again
engineers' efforts through May of 1983.
An interesting side note: VIKING 1's lander has been designated the
Thomas A. Mutch Memorial Station in honor of the late leader of the
lander imaging team. The National Air and Space Museum in Washington
D.C. is entrusted with the safekeeping of the Mutch Station Plaque until
it can be attached to the lander by a manned expedition.
VIKING 2 was launched on September 9
on August 7
column2: 1976. The lander touched down on September 3

column1: Utopia Planitia. It accomplished essentially the same tasks as its
sister lander
column2: with the exception that its seisometer worked

column1: one marsquake. The orbiter had a series of attitude-control gas leaks in

column2: which prompted it being shut down that July. The lander was shut

column1: down on April 12
The orbits of both VIKING orbiters should decay around 2025.
VOYAGER (OUTER PLANET FLYBYS)
VOYAGER 1 was launched September 5
column3: and flew past Jupiter on March

column1: August 20
column3: and flew by Jupiter on August 7

column1: by Neptune on August 8
column2: 1989. VOYAGER 2 took advantage of a rare

column1: once-every-189-years alignment to slingshot its way from outer planet to
outer planet. VOYAGER 1 could
but JPL opted for the sure thing of a Titan close up.
Between the two probes
column2: our knowledge of the 4 giant planets

column1: satellites
column2: and their rings has become immense. VOYAGER 1&2 discovered

column1: that Jupiter has complicated atmospheric dynamics
aurorae. Three new satellites were discovered. Two of the major
surprises were that Jupiter has rings and that Io has active sulfurous
volcanoes
column2: with major effects on the Jovian magnetosphere.

column1: When the two probes reached Saturn
and 7 satellites
column2: including the predicted shepherd satellites that keep

column1: the rings stable. The weather was tame compared with Jupiter: massive
jet streams with minimal variance (a 33-year great white spot/band cycle
is known). Titan's atmosphere was smoggy. Mimas' appearance was
startling: one massive impact crater gave it the Death Star appearance.
The big surprise here was the stranger aspects of the rings. Braids
kinks
column2: and spokes were both unexpected and difficult to explain.

column1: VOYAGER 2
column2: thanks to heroic engineering and programming efforts

column1: continued the mission to Uranus and Neptune. Uranus itself was highly
monochromatic in appearance. One oddity was that its magnetic axis was
found to be highly skewed from the already completely skewed rotational
axis
column2: giving Uranus a peculiar magnetosphere. Icy channels were found on

column1: Ariel
column2: and Miranda was a bizarre patchwork of different terrains. 10

column1: satellites and one more ring were discovered.
In contrast to Uranus
column2: Neptune was found to have rather active weather

column1: including numerous cloud features. The ring arcs turned out to be bright
patches on one ring. Two other rings
discovered. Neptune's magnetic axis was also skewed. Triton had a
canteloupe appearance and geysers. (What's liquid at 38K?)
The two VOYAGERs are expected to last for about two more decades. Their
on-target journeying gives negative evidence about possible planets
beyond Pluto. Their next major scientific discovery should be the
location of the heliopause.
SOVIET PLANETARY MISSIONS
Since there have been so many Soviet probes to the Moon
Mars
column2: I will highlight only the primary missions:

column1: SOVIET LUNAR PROBES
LUNA 1 - Lunar impact attempt in 1959
craft in solar orbit.
LUNA 2 - First craft to impact on lunar surface in 1959.
LUNA 3 - Took first images of lunar farside in 1959.
ZOND 3 - Took first images of lunar farside in 1965 since LUNA 3. Was
also a test for future Mars missions.
LUNA 9 - First probe to soft land on the Moon in 1966
from surface.
LUNA 10 - First probe to orbit the Moon in 1966.
LUNA 13 - Second successful Soviet lunar soft landing mission in 1966.
ZOND 5 - First successful circumlunar craft. ZOND 6 through 8
accomplished similar missions through 1970. The probes were
unmanned tests of a manned orbiting SOYUZ-type lunar vehicle.
LUNA 16 - First probe to land on Moon and return samples of lunar soil
to Earth in 1970. LUNA 20 accomplished similar mission in
LUNA 17 - Delivered the first unmanned lunar rover to the Moon's
surface
column3: in 1970. A similar feat was accomplished

column1: with LUNA 21/LUNOKHOD 2 in 1973.
LUNA 24 - Last Soviet lunar mission to date. Returned soil samples in
SOVIET VENUS PROBES
VENERA 1 - First acknowledged attempt at Venus mission. Transmissions
lost enroute in 1961.
VENERA 2 - Attempt to image Venus during flyby mission in tandem with
VENERA 3. Probe ceased transmitting just before encounter in
February of 1966. No images were returned.
VENERA 3 - Attempt to place a lander capsule on Venusian surface.
Transmissions ceased just before encounter and entire probe
became the first craft to impact on another planet in 1966.
VENERA 4 - First probe to successfully return data while descending
through Venusian atmosphere. Crushed by air pressure before
reaching surface in 1967. VENERA 5 and 6 mission profiles
similar in 1969.
VENERA 7 - First probe to return data from the surface of another planet
in 1970. VENERA 8 accomplished a more detailed mission in
VENERA 9 - Sent first image of Venusian surface in 1975. Was also the
first probe to orbit Venus. VENERA 10 accomplished similar
mission.
VENERA 13 - Returned first color images of Venusian surface in 1982.
VENERA 14 accomplished similar mission.
VENERA 15 - Accomplished radar mapping with VENERA 16 of sections of
planet's surface in 1983 more detailed than PVO.
VEGA 1 - Accomplished with VEGA 2 first balloon probes of Venusian
atmosphere in 1985
column2: including two landers. Flyby buses went on

column1: to become first spacecraft to study Comet Halley close-up in
March of 1986.
SOVIET MARS PROBES
MARS 1 - First acknowledged Mars probe in 1962. Transmissions ceased
enroute the following year.
ZOND 2 - First possible attempt to place a lander capsule on Martian
surface. Probe signals ceased enroute in 1965.
MARS 2 - First Soviet Mars probe to land - albeit crash - on Martian
surface. Orbiter section first Soviet probe to circle the Red
Planet in 1971.
MARS 3 - First successful soft landing on Martian surface
signals ceased after 90 seconds in 1971.
MARS 4 - Attempt at orbiting Mars in 1974
fire
column2: probe went on into solar orbit.

column1: MARS 5 - First fully successful Soviet Mars mission
1974. Returned images of Martian surface comparable to U.S.
probe MARINER 9.
MARS 6 - Landing attempt in 1974. Lander crashed into the surface.
MARS 7 - Lander missed Mars completely in 1974
with its flyby bus.
PHOBOS 1 - First attempt to land probes on surface of Mars' largest
moon
column2: Phobos. Probe failed enroute in 1988 due to

column1: human/computer error.
PHOBOS 2 - Attempt to land probes on Martian moon Phobos. The probe did
enter Mars orbit in early 1989
before scheduled Phobos landing.
While there has been talk of Soviet Jupiter
interstellar probes within the next thirty years
yet been taken with these projects. More intensive studies of the Moon
Mars
column3: and various comets have been planned for the 1990s

column1: Mercury mission to orbit and land probes on the tiny world has been
planned for 2003. How the many changes in the former Soviet Union (now
the Commonwealth of Independent States) will affect the future of their
space program remains to be seen.
JAPANESE PLANETARY MISSIONS
SAKIGAKE (MS-T5) was launched from the Kagoshima Space Center by ISAS on
January 8 1985
column2: and approached Halley's Comet within about 7 million km

column1: on March 11
column2: 1986. The spacecraft is carrying three instru- ments to

column1: measure interplanetary magnetic field/plasma waves/solar wind
which work normally now
column2: so ISAS made an Earth swingby by Sakigake on

column1: January 8
column2: 1992 into an orbit similar to the earth's. The closest

column1: approach was at 23h08m47s (JST=UTC+9h) on January 8
geocentric distance was 88
column2: 997 km. This is the first planet-swingby for

column1: a Japanese spacecraft.
During the approach
column2: Sakigake observed the geotail. Some geotail

column1: passages will be scheduled in some years hence. The second Earth-swingby
will be on June 14
October 28
HITEN
column3: was launched into Earth orbit on January 24

column1: 1990. The spacecraft was then known as MUSES-A
once in orbit. The 430 lb probe looped out from Earth and made its first
lunary flyby on March 19
column2: where it dropped off its 26 lb midget

column1: satellite
column2: HAGOROMO. Japan at this point became the third nation to

column1: orbit a satellite around the Moon
column2: joining the Unites States and USSR.

column1: The smaller spacecraft
column3: remained in orbit around the Moon. An

column1: apparently broken transistor radio caused the Japanese space scientists
to lose track of it. Hagoromo's rocket motor fired on schedule on March

column2: but the spacecraft's tracking transmitter failed immediately. The

column1: rocket firing of Hagoromo was optically confirmed using the Schmidt
camera (105-cm
column2: F3.1) at the Kiso Observatory in Japan.

column1: Hiten made multiple lunar flybys at approximately monthly intervals and
performed aerobraking experiments using the Earth's atmosphere. Hiten
made a close approach to the moon at 22:33 JST (UTC+9h) on February 15
1992 at the height of 423 km from the moon's surface (35.3N
fired its propulsion system for about ten minutes to put the craft into
lunar orbit. The following is the orbital calculation results after the
approach:
Apoapsis Altitude: about 49
Periapsis Altitude: about 9
Inclination	: 34.7 deg (to ecliptic plane)
Period		: 4.7 days
PLANETARY MISSION REFERENCES
I also recommend reading the following works
groups: General overviews
column2: specific books on particular space missions

column1: and periodical sources on space probes. This list is by no means
complete; it is primarily designed to give you places to start your
research through generally available works on the subject. If anyone can
add pertinent works to the list
Though naturally I recommend all the books listed below
would be best if you started out with the general overview books
order to give you a clear idea of the history of space exploration in
this area. I also recommend that you pick up some good
general works on astronomy and the Sol system
background. Most of these books and periodicals can be found in any good
public and university library. Some of the more recently published works
can also be purchased in and/or ordered through any good mass- market
bookstore.

SPACE MISSION
Carl Sagan
information records placed on VOYAGER 1 and 2 in case the
probes are found by intelligences in interstellar space
as well as the probes and planetary mission objectives
themselves.)
Other works and periodicals:
NASA has published very detailed and technical books on every space
probe mission it has launched. Good university libraries will carry
these books
column2: and they are easily found simply by knowing which mission

column1: you wish to read about. I recommend these works after you first study
some of the books listed above.
Some periodicals I recommend for reading on space probes are NATIONAL
GEOGRAPHIC
column2: which has written articles on the PIONEER probes to Earth's

column1: Moon Luna and the Jovian planets Jupiter and Saturn
SURVEYOR
missions to Mercury
VOYAGER missions to Jupiter
More details on American
can be found in SKY AND TELESCOPE
SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN magazines. TIME
newspapers can supply not only general information on certain missions
but also show you what else was going on with Earth at the time events
were unfolding
column2: if that is of interest to you. Space missions are

column1: affected by numerous political
probably know.
Depending on just how far your interest in space probes will go
might also wish to join The Planetary Society
groups in the world dedicated to planetary exploration. Their
periodical
missions. Write to The Planetary Society
Pasadena
Good luck with your studies in this area of space exploration. I
personally find planetary missions to be one of the more exciting areas
in this field
column2: and the benefits human society has and will receive from

column1: it are incredible
column2: with many yet to be realized.

For a VGA card these are the correct files but you can't just copy them
back and expect it to work.  You have to create a new WIN.COM file.  Try
the command (you will have to worry about what directories each file is in
since I don't know your setup):
COPY /B WIN.CNF+VGALOGO.LGO+VGALOGO.RLE WIN.COM
(I grabbed this from _Supercharging Windows_ by Judd Robbins--great book)
This is also how you can put your own logo into the Windows startup screen.
An RLE file is just a specially compressed BMP file.
Hope this helps"

1119|The BusLogic cards have an OS/2 2.0 driver that does work with the March 2.1
beta. Support for the BusLogic cards is not included with OS/2 2.0 any longer.
If you wish to install the beta from the CD/ROM
column2: you will need to REM out the

column1: Adaptec device drivers
column2: as they have a nasty tendency to crash the BusLogic

column1: cards when OS/2 attempts to use them. (Thanks Adaptec!)
So you add the BusLogic drivers to the config.sys on the CD-ROM boot disk
REM out the Adaptec drivers.
Then you install the whole 1st half of the Beta.. and it won't work! IBM
nicely copies in the Adaptec drivers once again. (Thanks IBM!) So.. REM out
the Adaptec drivers once more.. and reboot. If you have everything in the
right order.. it will work.
Things are pretty smooth through the rest of the installation.. except OS/2
will try to install the Adaptec SCSI drivers once again at the end... so.. you
are off to more REM statements and more fun.
The BT 542Bk comes with drivers and costs the same as the Adaptec cards that
do not come with drivers. The DOS drivers work great. This card can easily be
configured to work with 8 different sets of I/O ports (and you can use
multiple host adapters in one machine) If you get a new card.. it will also be
able to support up to 8 GB drives under DOS.
Hope this helps..
- Dan

Request for opinions:
Which is better - a one-piece Aerostitch or a two-piece Aerostitch?

1-pc is better protection

Nadine
What is best? Books have been written on that! But in regard to
AeroStich it really depends on your particular size
If you upper and lower body are not proportional (according to aero
dimensions) then it probably is going to be better mixing and matching
the 2 piece suit. I have the 2 piece suit and I am very happy with it.
Having my life quota of scars from crashing off road
concerned with good protection and I believe that the difference in
protection between the 1 and 2 piece suits is almost negligible. I
think the optional hip pads and back protector make much more of a
difference. One thing that is nice about the 2 piece is if you go
somewhere and then want to walk around for a while (still with jacket)
you can just detach and stow the pants.
One thing to note is that Goldfine has problems getting a good fit for
many women (with standard suits). Supposedly for smaller women (and
petite men for that matter) the 1 piece will fit better.
Another recommendation is to pay for mods if you need them. I wish I
got 2-3 inches added to my pant legs. I find the Long suits are not
really that long (I can't imagine how short the standard suits must
be).

Any machine powered by heat (motor
thermoelement
between input and output is. Because You never get all thermic energy out of
the powering medium (steam
column4: You have to eliminate the rest

column1: of the energy to keep the efficency high. A thermal electric power plant (coal
oil or atomic power) works just the same way. You heat water (steam) to power
the turbine and generators. Because You don't get the whole energy out of the
steam (efficency is never 100%) You have to cool down this steam again by
something else. Most power plants use cooling towers for this purpose (some
type of mega-refrigerator...). Others use water of a river (ecologically not
unobjectionable). Got it ?

Some motherboards support VL bus and 50-DX CPU.  There is an option
(BIOS I think) where additional wait(s) can be added with regard to
CPU/VL bus transactions.  This slows the CPU down to a rate that gives
the VL bus device(s) time to 'do their thing'.  These particular wait(s)
are applied when the CPU transacts with VL bus device(s).  You want to
enable these wait(s) only if you are using a 50-DX with VL bus devices.
This is from reading my motherboard manual
tations.  Your mileage may vary.
Strictly speaking
column2: VL and 50mhz are not compatable.  And

I am puzzled by the term ""concept."" Drag free may already have
been flown. It was the idea behind putting up a spacecraft that would
more accurately respond to motions from the Earth's gravity field and
ignore drag. It was proposed many years ago and involved a ball
floating between sensors whose job it was to signal to little
adjustment jets to keep the ball away from them. The ball itself would
then be in a drag free condition and respond only to gravity
anisotropies
column2: whereas the spacecraft itself would be continuously

column1: adjusting its position to compensate for drag.

CONTROLLER VS52
The purpose of the controller is to enter the TV images into a IBM
PC AT or any other machine of that type. The controller was
created on the base of modern elements
programmable gate arrays.
The controller allows to digitize a input signal with different
resolutions. Its flexible architecture makes possible to change
technical parameters. Instead of TV signal one can process any
other analog signal (including signals from slow-speed scanning
devices).

- resolution when working with standard video signal - from 64x64
to 1024x512 pixels ;

I can only comment on thermal recalibration in general. Some new
drives perform it in order to increase overall integrity of data
writes. Basically
column2: the firmware instructs the actuator to perform

column1: a test to see if the data tracks are within a certain physical
tolerance
column2: since when the media heats up or cools down

column1: track drift is inevitable
column2: and the drive has to monitor it. This

column1: becomes especially critical at very high recording densities
so was used primarily on very large-capacity mechanisms
seems to be finding its way into more smaller drives as a way of
boosting the drive's long-term reliability and MTBF ratings.
I first became aware of thermal recalibration when it was pointed
out that the technique conflicts with prolonged write times when
digitizing
column3: audio or video to hard disk. Some manufacturers

column1: explicitly state that drives with thermal recalibration are NOT
to be used for applications that have prolonged disk writes.
Hope this helps."

Commonly Asked Automotive Questions
Tire Questions:
Q:  What do the funny numbers on the sides of my tires mean?
A:  Typically
column2: you will see something like 195/60HR14.  the 195 is the

column1: overall width of the tire in millimeters
narrower.  The 60 is the `aspect ratio'; it indicates the height of the
sidewall of the tire relative to the overall width.  Our example tire
has a sidewall height of 0.60 * 195 ~= 117 mm.  The 14 is the wheel
diameter in inches; there are also some special tires called `TRX'
tires which have three digit metric wheel diameter designations

column2: which is in millimeters.  The R means Radial
column3: and the H is a speed

column1: rating indicating the highest speed at which the tire
inflated and carrying an appropriate load
speed ratings are S (112MPH)
Recent changes to the method for specifying tire sizes move the speed
rating to a different part of the designation; you may therefore find
designations like 195/60R14 85H; the 85 indicates the per-tire load
associated with the speed rating -- exceeding this load in continuous
operation at the rated speed is dangerous practice.  What follows is
a table showing a number of `load indices' and corresponding maximum
per-tire loads:
Note that the usual mass vs. weight confusion occurs in this table.
In some cases

indicates Passenger car.  If no letter is given
of the tire is Passenger car usage.  As far as I know

the owner of a passenger vehicle
between a tire with a P designation and one with no designation at

If the aspect ratio is omitted
Tires with an MS (mud/snow) designation may have their speed rating
reduced by 20 km/h (about 12mph.)
There is an additional set of ratings on tires for temperature
traction
column2: and treadwear.  Temperature and Traction are graded

column1: A
column3: and C (with A the best and C the worst); treadwear is

column1: a numeric rating.  These values are of limited value

Q:  My car has tires with a funny size designation:  185/65HR390; can i put
normal tires on the car?
A:  Your tires are called TRX tires; they were devised by Michelin.
Because of a somewhat different bead design
with normal tires; Michelin used a different diameter wheel for them
so that they could not be mounted on the wrong type wheel (and so that
more conventional tires could not be mounted on TRX type wheels.)
You will need to aquire different wheels to put a normal tire on your
car; it is barely possible to fit normal tires on TRX wheels
dangerous to do so (the tires may simply peel off the rims in a corner
or possibly blow out at high speed.)  TRX type tires are becoming hard
to find; in addition to Michelin
has apparently discontinued their line of TRX tires.
Q:  Can I rotate radials from side to side
column2: or rotate them only on one side

column1: of my car?
A:  Car and tire manufacturers have differing views on this subject; many
say that swapping radials between the left and right hand sides of a
car is now ok (this group includes Michelin and Goodyear); others
(for example
column2: Pirelli and Nokia) will void warranties if such swapping

column1: is done.  The best advice is to read your tire manual carefully before
rotating your tires
column2: and stick to the manufacturer's recommendations.

column1: Radar Detectors and Speed Limits:

misc.consumers and rec.autos.* always start long
flame wars.  If you want to talk about either of these topics

Brake Questions:
Q:  Do I always need to get the rotors on my disk brakes turned?  Midas
always wants to do this.
A:  No.  There are specific conditions that mandate turning or replacing
rotors; some shops try and make a little extra money by replacing rotors
more often than is strictly necessary.  if the rotors are not warped
warped
column3: then there is no need to replace or

column1: to turn them.  Note also that some rotors (the rotors on many Hondas
are a good example) are so narrow to begin with that it is not practical
to turn them; they must be replaced when they become too thin
or badly grooved.
Q:  They tell me I should downshift when braking to slow my car down.  Is
this really a good idea?
A:  It used to be a very good idea
column2: back in the days of mediocre

column1: prone drum brakes.  In modern disc brake equipped cars
downshifting to slow the car is not really necessary
of long
than adequate to stop a passenger car in all circumstances
are much cheaper to repair than clutch linings.
On the other hand
column2: many standard driver's license tests in the USA

column1: still specify that the driver being tested downshift under braking; I
suggest that before taking a US driver's test
do this smoothly (which takes some time and practice) or 2) borrow a
car with an automatic to take the test.
Q:  How often should I replace my brake fluid?
A:  Probably more often than you do.  Traditional brake fluids tend to
absorb water; this water can corrode internal parts of the brake
system and also lower the boiling point of the fluid.  DOT-3 type
are older fluids; DOT-4 and DOT-5 are newer specifications.  The
principal differences are in wet and dry boiling points; the dry
boiling point is important in fresh brake fluid
point is important in older brake fluid.  DOT-3 fluids have the lowest
wet and dry boiling point _requirements_; DOT-4 fluids have better
boiling point requirements; and DOT-5 fluids have the best boiling
point requirements (but DOT-5 fluids are not clearly superior; see
the next Q&A for more details.)  While the requirements imply that
DOT-4 fluids are better than DOT-3 fluids
cases where a DOT-3 fluid is preferable
competition applications.  Otherwise
improved brake pedal feel.  Replacement once a year is recommended for
DOT-4 fluids
column2: although agressive drivers may profit by changing out

column1: fluid more frequently
column2: or at least bleeding a modest amount of fluid

column1: out of the brake calipers fairly regularly.
Q:  What about DOT-5 brake fluids?
A:  This breaks down in to two parts.  The DOT-5 specification looks
excellent for performance
column2: but the first DOT-5 fluids were Silicone

column1: based.  Silicone fluids are a tricky proposition.  Unlike DOT-3 and
DOT-4 fluids
column2: they do not absorb water at all.  While this may sound

column1: like a feature
column2: the problem is that any water present pools up in

column1: such systems
column2: interfering with braking performance and corroding any

column1: metals at the spot where the pooling is occuring.  The water will tend
to migrate downwards in the braking system to the brake calipers
most of the corrosion occurs.
Because of this phenomenon
column2: it is essential when converting to

column1: Silicone to empty the entire brake system and flush it throughly
beforehand; some even recommend replacing all rubber parts in the
brake system when converting to Silicone fluids.
Two other issues that come up with silicone fluids:  1) they are
difficult to pour cleanly (that is
interferes with getting a good brake pedal feel
generally have much higher boiling points than DOT-4 fluids
do have high temperature failure modes which are indistinguishable
in effect from boiling DOT-4 fluids.  SIlicone fluids may make sense
in some street car applications
recommended for high performance driving applications
economics are questionable for street use.
I have recently become aware of new fluids that meet the DOT-5 standard
that do not contain Silicones; these fluids appear to be reasonably
compatible with the older DOT-3 and DOT-4 fluids
information at this time.

A:  This does not have a cut and dried answer; therefore
be quite long in order to cover the pros and cons.  The short answer
is that ABS costs more
work better for the `average driver' (that is to say

Now for the long answer.  ABS works by monitering the wheels of the

Gas Questions:
Q:  Does High Octane gasoline help?

Q:  My car was made for leaded gasoline.  Will unleaded gas hurt it?

although the Amoco Oil company argues otherwise.  The actual increase

check your owner's manual; many cars from the early 1970s do not
actually require leaded gasoline.
Q:  Do fuel treatments help?  What kind should I use?
A:  Some do and some don't.  During the winter
column2: it is a good idea to use

column1: dry gas; however
column2: some may be harmful to fuel injection systems.

column1: Never use an additive containing Methanol (sometimes called Methyl
Alcohol); such additives may damage fuel systems in cars with carbs
and almost certainly will damage cars with fuel injection.
Manufacturer's opinions vary on additives containing Ethanol (sometimes
called Ethyl Alcohol); if your car has fuel injection
manual on your car before  using these.  Most manufacturers consider
10% Ethanol acceptable in gasoline.  Additives with Isopropyl Alcohol
(Isopropanol)
column2: and Petroleum  Distillates are fine in fuel injected

column1: cars.
An occasional bottle of fuel injector cleaner is helpful in cars with
fuel injectors
column2: although many premium gasolines contain detergents that

column1: do the same job.  Some off brands of fuel injector cleaners contain
Ethanol or Methanol; always check the ingredients before putting anything
in your gas tank.
There are a small number of particularly good additives; these are
noticeably more expensive that the run-of-the-mill ones
much
column2: much better.  Among these are Chevron Techron

column1: Wurth `Lubrimoly Ventil Sauber'
column2: and BG 44K.  A bottle of one of these

column1: once every six months
Q:  What about detergent gasolines?
A:  The quality of detergent packages in gasolines varies somewhat; BMW
has instituted a testing program
column2: and gasoline brands which pass this

column1: test may advertise that fact.  Stickers indicating passage of the test
are now beginning to appear on fuel pumps at gas stations.  If such
gasolines are used
column2: then fuel injector cleaners are probably optional.

column1: Beforewarned that while use of BMW approved gasolines will keep a clean
engine clean
column2: they may not clean a motor with bad valve deposits.

column1: Lubrication Questions:
Q:  What do the numbers and letters in a motor oil designation mean?
A:  There are several different items encoded.  There is a two-letter
code indicating the type of detergent package that the manufacturer
uses in the oil; this looks like SE
column3: CD or such.  The S codes are

column1: for gasoline engine applications; the C codes are for diesel engine
applications.  The second letter is assigned in sequence as new levels
of protection are developed; thus SF is considered better than SE
SE is considered better than SD
The more noticeable designation is the oil weight.  This is either
a single number (e.g.
column2: 30 weight) or a pair of numbers separated by

column1: the letter W (e.g.
column2: 10W30.)  The latter type is much more commonly

column1: used these days
column2: and are the only type that most automobile

column1: manufacturers specify in operators manuals.  The first number in the
designation (10W) is the apparent viscosity of the oil when it is cold;
the W stands for `winter'.  The second number (30) is the viscosity
of the oil when hot.  There is a trick here; the oil doesn't actually
get thicker (turn from 10 weight to 30 weight) as it gets hotter.  What
is actually happening is that when the oil is cold
of a cold 10 weight oil.  as it gets hotter
column2: it doesn't get thin as fast

column1: as a 10W oil would; by the time it is up to temperature
viscosity of a hot 30 weight oil.
Note that these numbers actually specify ranges of viscosities; not
all 10W oils have exactly the same viscosity when cold
30 weight oils have the same viscosity when hot.  Note also that the
novel behaviour of multi-grade oils is caused by additives
been reported that with the sole exception of Castrol GTX
do not retain their multi-grade characteristics well over time.  10W30
Q:  Are `quick lube' places any good?
A:  Some do adequate work
column2: but there are quite a few incompetent ones out

column1: there.  Let the buyer beware
that they don't overtorque the oil drain plug
your wallet at all times.
Q:  Are oil additives like Slick-50 or Tufoil any good?
A:  Slick-50 and Tufoil are PTFE-based additives.  Many of these have
come onto the market recently; they are different from the moly-based
additives that have been around since the early 50's.  PTFE is the
chemical name for Teflon(TM)
column2: a trademark owned by DuPont. In general

column1: auto manufacturers do not recommend use of these products.  Most USENET
responses to questions on these additives are favorable (slight
increase of MPG after application
results (whether PTFE additives are effective after 5K miles) are
debatable.  Some manufacturers (such as Saab) claim that either the
product or the engine flush that preceeds application causes
deterioration of the oil seals and eventual leakage.  Some BMW owners
have reported death of valve seals shortly after the addition of
Slick 50 to their cars.  This writer has been cautioned by a Slick-50
Dealer (!) that Slick-50 should _not_ be used in Japanese motors
it may clog the oil return passages in the engine.  Otherwise
no known reports of damage caused by PTFE additives.
On the other hand
column2: there are satified Slick 50 customers in the world.

column1: Q:  Do synthetic oils really work?
A:  Yes
but disagree with the extremely long oil change intervals claimed by
oil manufacturers.  Auto manufacturers recommend that you continue to
change oil at the intervals recommended in the owners manual for your
car.  Even if you decide to try the longer intervals
the oil filter at regular intervals
column2: as synthetics get just as dirty

column1: as conventional oils.
Synthetic gear lubricants for manual transmissions are another matter
entirely; Amsoil
column3: and AGIP are very highly regarded and very

column1: effective.  Mobil 1 synthetic gear lube gets mixed reviews
Q:  Manufacturers are specifying longer and longer oil change intervals.
How often should I change my oil?
A:  It depends on how you drive.  If your car always (or nearly always)
gets warmed up
column2: and you don't drive it very hard and keep the revs

column1: down
column2: the manufacturer's recommendation is probably fine.  If

column1: you drive it hard
only drive it to and from the supermarket so that it doesn't get up
to temperature
column2: then you may wish to change oil much more often

column1: perhaps at 3000 mile intervals (given that most manufacturers are
now specifying 7500 mile intervals.)  If you don't drive your car
much at all (say 7500 miles a year)
column2: then you probably want to change

column1: oil every six months anyway.  If you are storing a car during the winter
then change oil before storing it and change oil when you bring it out
of storage.
Misc. Questions:
Q:  My car has a timing belt.  I hear that bad things happen when they
break.  What's the story?
A:  It depends on the internal design of the motor.  Early Ford Escorts
for example
column2: will suffer severe valve damage if the belt breaks

column1: the newer cars will just require a tow and installation of a new belt.
Some Honda motors will not be damaged
If no replacement interval is specified for your car
belt at least every 60
column2: 000 miles; some cars may require more frequent

column1: replacement.  Ask your dealer or independent mechanic.  Also
there are any related repairs that should take place at the same time
(for example
column2: the same Ford Escorts that suffer valve damage also have

column1: a timing belt driven water pump
column2: which has been known to seize

column1: destroying the timing belt
column2: and which then causes major valve damage

column1: as a side effect.  Replacing the timing belt while ignoring the water
pump can be a costly mistake.)
Q:  Why would anyone be stupid enough to design a motor so that it
self destructs when the timing belt breaks?
A:  For performance reasons.  Compromising piston design so that the
valves and pistons will not collide requires that the compression
ratio of the engine be reduced significantly; this is why you are
more likely to avoid valve damage in economy cars than in performance
oriented vehicles.
Q:  What causes Unintended Acceleration?
A:  The final report of the National Highway
Administration concluded that unintended acceleration could not be
caused by any mechanical failure of the vehicle in question and at the
same time be consistent with the physical evidence.  The NHTSA report
goes on to conclude that `pedal misapplication' by the vehicle operator
is probably the cause."

column2: the cooling towers on nuclear power plants

column1: are vertually identical in construction and operation to cooling
towers designed and built in the 1890's (a hundred years ago) for
coal fired power plants used for lighting and early electric railways.
Basicly
column2: the cylindrical tower supports a rapid air draft when

column1: its air is heated by hot water and/or steam circulating thru a network
of pipes that fill about the lower 1/3 of the tower. To assist cooling
and the draft
column2: water misters are added that spray cold water over the

column1: hot pipes. The cold water evaporates
just air flow from the draft would and the resulting water vapor is
rapidly carried away by the draft. This produces the clouds frequently
seen rising out of these towers.
That slight pinch (maybe 2/3 of the way up the tower) is there because
it produces a very significant increase in the strength and rate of
the air draft produced
column2: compared to a straight cylinder shape.

column1: The towers are used to recondense the steam in the sealed steam
system of the power plant so that it can be recirculated back to the
boiler and used again. The wider the temperature difference across
the turbines used in the power plant the more effecient they are and
by recondensing the steam in the cooling towers before sending it
back to the boilers you maintain a very wide temperature difference
(sometimes as high as 1000 degrees or more from first stage ""hot""
turbine to final stage ""cold"" turbine).
R. Tim Coslet"

column1: Sphinx is a user-friendly
and analysis package that runs across a spectrum of high performance
computer platforms operating UNIX and the X-Window System.
It was created to meet to the daily research needs of scientists
conducting climate investigations using satellite data and remote
sensing techniques.
Intuitive Graphic Interface
Sphinx features an interactive interface with pop-up menus and
point-and-click dialog boxes which makes image processing and
analysis simple and fast.
This accessible menuing enables you to build attractive image
layouts quickly while also providing you the flexibility of returning
to the main menu to conduct other image analysis and processing operations.
Image Format Compatibility
Using smart read/write functions
column2: Sphinx allows you to easily open

column1: and save image files in a variety of formats using bit
data values.  Sphinx also reads and writes the common TIFF and GIF formats
as well as compresses and decompresses image formats to save disk space.
Image Analysis & Processing
For image and pixel analysis
assortment of processing tools that perform useful statistical and
mathematical filtering operations
product or principal component analyses.
An interactive interpreter for both algebraic equations and images allows
the user to manipulate and combine individual data channels interactively.
Standard FORTRAN notation is used for formula entry and for trig
onometric and transcendental functions.
Satellite Spectra & Orbit Analysis
Sphinx possesses functions to simulate satellite signal sensitivity
for various meteorological satellites (e.g.
The simulations are conducted for a selection of standard atmospheric and
surface conditions and instrument spectral bands.
A geometry model computes the solar zenith angles
and 3-D image projection.
Easy External Program Interfacing
Sphinx allows users the flexibility to integrate externally
developed software algorithms for processing and converting satellite
observations.  Sphinx exports and imports image files and image parameters
to external programs using special interface functions.
Quick Quality Presentation
Sphinx rapidly displays
multispectral images and color tables.  Using six 8-bit 1024x1024 image
planes and one graphics plane
column2: the package conveniently combines color images

column1: graphics and text to generate sharp digital images for articles and reports.
Sphinx's 2-D and 3-D graphics editor provides complete flexibility for modifying
and integrating vector graphics and analysis plots with images
histograms and radial graphs.  The package supplies color and gray scale
output for standard inkjet and laser printers.
Other Capabilities Sphinx also performs image animation
graphics importing
Software Support & Development
Sphinx was developed at the Laboratoire d'Optique Atmospherique (LOA)
of the Universite de Lille
The package has received critical feedback and support from scientists at
the French national laboratory
and the French space agency
At LOA
column2: Sphinx undergoes continued refinement and development to meet changing

column1: research needs and advances in computer technology.  The package
on-line help
column2: is supported by an Internet address

column1: sphinx@loasil.citilille.fr through which questions can be answered and
version updates provided without delay.
Performance Tested
CNES has selected Sphinx to analyze and process the satellite data
collected during the upcoming ADEOS/POLDER satellite mission.  Today
the Sphinx package is in use at the NASA - Goddard Space Flight Center
and is widely used in many French laboratories
the Centre de Recherche en Physique de l'Environnement
Laboratoire d' Etudes et de Recherches en Teledetection Spatiale
de Meteorologie Dynamique.
A TEST VERSION OF SPHINX IS AVAILABLE AT loasil.citilille.fr
(134.206.50.4) anonymous (bin : cd SPHINX : get ALL_SPHINX.tar.Z)
IN THE TEST VERSION THE OUTPUT FILES ARE DISABLE. HOWEVER THE
VISUALISATION AND GRAPHIC FUNCTIONS ARE AVAILABLE. THIS IS

ps-ipu unit (postscript intelligent processing unit)
Hello
We have recently purchased a very expensive and nice color copier/printer.
We want to be able to print to it from our SGI iris network.  The
copier/printer has both a parallel and SCSI interface.  I have configured the
printer with the ""lp"" system using the parallel interface and can print
postscript files to the printer.  I can also print rgb files
turn converted to postscript by an internal filter.  The Canon CLC 500 is a
publication quality printer but the quality of our postscript printouts
are less than acceptable.  We create the postscript files with a variaty of
programs
column4: and tops.  When we convert to postscript

column1: with tops and use the -l option to specify the halftone screen density of 98
rather than the default 40 the output is better
acceptable.  Note
column2: that we are starting with a screen image in rgb image format

column1: and translating the image into postscript.
We suspect that if we could use the SCSI interface we would get higher quality
pictures.  We have not purchased the software that drives the printer from the
SCSI port.  To my knowledge this software is $5000 and does not come with a
warranty.  The management here does not want to spend this much money without
some assurance that the product will work.
Here my questions:
If anybody on the net uses this printer are you using the SCSI or
parallel port?  What is the quality of the printouts?
Is there a way to create high quality postscript printouts?  What is the
limiting component

Something to bear in mind is what the V in VLB stands for!
V for Video - the origional intention of the bus was to speed up
the bus so that large memory to memory transfers would be faster.
This is espically useful in transfering data from main memory to
video memory.
Since there are usually 3 VLB slots card makers have been making
cards to fit in the other two.
How about an VLB ethernet card? Move the data into the card at
130 odd MB/s and then wait for it to tickle onto the net at
just over 1Mb/s.
[ Do do however free the local bus for other cards ]
Some times you need fast busses and sometimes you don't!
Guy"

column2: The neutral wire is current carrying and the ground wire

column2: or only during a fault condition.

column1: The reason the neutral and ground are tied together in the panel is the
tranformer on the power pole has a grounded center-tap secondary
grounded center-tap the neutral.  This gives 120v to neutral(ground) from
each side of the transformer and 240v across the transformer.  So in effect
the neutral and ground should be at the same potential.

I agree with everything that Lee Lady wrote in her previous post in
this thread.  In case this puzzles people
on two of her comments.
One of the most important (and difficult) aspects of reasoning
about empirical investigation lies in understanding the context
scope
column2: and importance of the various arguments and pieces of

column1: evidence that are marshalled for a claim.  Some errors break the
back of a piece of research
column2: some leave a hole that needs to be

column1: filled in
column2: and some are trivial in their importance.  It is a

column1: grave mistake to confuse these.
Past snippets from this thread:
Back to Lee Lady:
These posters are making the mistake that I have previously
criticized of adhering to a methodological recipe.  A ""carefully
designed and controlled study"" is neither always possible nor
always important.  (On the other hand
remedy that supposedly alleviates a chronic medical problem
have enough knowledge of the errors that have plagued *this* kind
of claim to ask for a ""carefully designed and controlled study""
to alleviate our skepticism.)
Rules such as ""support the hypothesis by a carefully designed and
controlled study"" are too narrow to apply to *all* investigation.
I think that the requirements for particular reasoning to be
convincing depends greatly on the kinds of mistakes that have
occurred in past reasoning about the same kinds of things.  (To
reuse the previous example
uncontrolled observations of the treatment of chronic medical
problems are notoriously problematic.)  "

column1: There are several problems with this.  The most serious is that the
Law was regarded by Jews at the time (and now) as binding on Jews
not on Gentiles.  There are rules that were binding on all human
beings (the so-called Noachic laws)
column2: but they are quite minimal.  The

column1: issue that the Church had to face after Jesus' death was what to do
about Gentiles who wanted to follow Christ.  The decision not to
impose the Law on them didn't say that the Law was abolished.  It
simply acknowledged that fact that it didn't apply to Gentiles.  This
is a simple answer
column2: which I think just about everyone can agree to.

column1: (A discussion of the issue in more or less these terms is recorded
in Acts 15.)
However there's more involved.  In order to get a full picture of the
role of the Law
column2: we have to come to grips with Paul's apparent

column1: rejection of the Law
column2: and how that relates to Jesus' commendation of

column1: the Law.  At least as I read Paul
column2: he says that the Law serves a

column1: purpose that has been in a certain sense superceded.  Again
issue isn't one of the abolition of the Law.  In the middle of his
discussion
column2: Paul notes that he might be understood this way

column1: assures us that that's not what he intends to say.  Rather
the Law as primarily being present to convict people of their
sinfulness.  But ultimately it's an impossible standard
has been superceded by Christ.  Paul's comments are not the world's
clearest here
column2: and not everyone agrees with my reading.  But the

column1: interesting thing to notice is that even this radical position does
not entail an abolition of the Law.  It still remains as an
uncompromising standard
column2: from which not an iota or dot may be removed.

column1: For its purpose of convicting of sin
column2: it's important that it not be

column1: relaxed.  However for Christians
column2: it's not the end -- ultimately we

column1: live in faith

end I think Jesus and Paul come to a rather similar conclusion.  The
quoted passage from Mat 5 should be taken in the context of the rest
of the Sermon on the Mount
column2: where Jesus shows us how he interprets the

column1: Law.  The ""not an iota or dot"" would suggest a rather literal reading
but in fact that's not Jesus' approach.  Jesus' interpretations
emphasize the intent of the Law
column2: and stay away from the ceremonial

column1: details.  Indeed he is well known for taking a rather free attitude
towards the Sabbath and kosher laws.  Some scholars claim that Mat
5:17-20 needs to be taken in the context of 1st Cent. Jewish
discussions.  Jesus accuses his opponents of caring about giving a
tenth of even the most minor herbs
really matter: justice
column3: and caring about how cups and

the discussion later in Mat 5
column2: suggest that Jesus has a very specific

column1: view of the Law in mind
column2: and that when he talks about maintaining the

column1: Law in its full strength
column2: he is thinking of these aspects of it.

column1: Paul's conclusion is similar.  While he talks about the Law being
superceded
column2: all of the specific examples he gives involve the

column1: ceremonial law""
column2: such as circumcision and the Sabbath.  He is quite

column1: concerned about maintaining moral standards.
The net result of this is that when Paul talks about the Law being
superceded
column2: and Jesus talks about the Law being maintained

responding to specific situations
column2: he's looking at the aspect of the

ceremonies.  He certainly does not intend to abolish divine standards
of conduct.  On the other hand
to be talking the Law in its broadest implications for morals and

column2: it likely was part of a collection of

column1: documents
law registry].""

have a copy of a Nazi law?"" melts away

Nazi Weapons Law after his service at Nurnberg

column2: can be put aside as red

column1: herrings.

the history of Nazism and gun confiscation""

Registration of guns

column2: KDKA Radio News.  We're here at the Pittsburgh

Q	  There are a lot of things we'd like to talk

breaking from Los Angeles.  I guess the entire country has been

column2: wondering what's going to happen in

column1: the trial of the four Los Angeles police officers.  We just heard

Officer Powell have been found guilty
found not guilty.

year since the first trial and now this trial and this verdict.
And I wonder what your thoughts are this morning on how you see
the situation in Los Angeles in connection with your
administration and what you're trying to do.
THE PRESIDENT:  Well
American people should know that this trial
tribute to the work and judgment of the jury
efforts of the federal government in developing the case.
The law under which the officers were tried is a
complex one; the standards of proof are complicated.  The jury
decided that they would convict the sergeant who was responsible
for supervising the officers and the officer who on the film did
most of the beating.  The jury acquitted an officer who kicked

it appears that they really tried to do justice here.  They
acknowledged that his civil rights were violated.  And I think
that the American people should take a lot of pride in that.  But
I hope now we can begin to look ahead and focus on three things:
first of all
column2: the importance of trying to bring this country

column1: together and not violate the civil rights of any American;
secondly
column2: the importance of renewing our fight against crime.

country
column2: people may be worried about police abuse

column1: even more worried about crime.  It's time that we renewed our

waiting period before people could buy a handgun
other things to reduce the vulnerability of our people to

And the last point I'd like to make is it seems to
me that we have got to rededicate ourselves to the economic
revitalization of our cities and other economically-distressed
areas.  If you just think about it -- if everybody in Los Angeles
who wanted a job had one
column2: I don't think we'd have quite as many

column1: problems as we do.
And I laid out a very ambitious program in the
campaign to try to bring private investment and public investment
to bear in our cities.  I have dispatched the Commerce Secretary
Ron Brown
column2: to California to try to come up with some strategies

column1: for that state
column2: because it's our biggest state with our highest

column1: unemployment rate -- which could then be applied around the
country.  I want to talk to him and to the Attorney General
the new head of the NAACP
other people
column2: and then I'll decide where to go from here with

column1: regard to Los Angeles and the other cities of the country.
Q	  Let's talk about what brings you to the
Pittsburgh area today.  There have been -- I guess there's been a
lot of discussion on Capitol Hill about your stimulus package.
You've been locked in a battle with the GOP.  Yesterday
said earlier in your radio address
column2: you made some moves to break

column1: that gridlock.  What brings you to Pittsburgh
Allegheny County
battle?
THE PRESIDENT:  Well
of all
me in the last election because they wanted a new direction in
economic policy.  We have passed our overall economic plan; it
gives the country a very different budget for the next five years
than we've had in the previous 12.  We reduced the deficit and
at the same time
column2: increased investment in jobs and education and

column1: health care
column2: in the things that will make us a stronger country.

column1: But in addition to that
column2: I asked the Congress in the

column1: short run to spend a little more money
to create another half-million jobs in the next year and a half;
to try to cut the unemployment rate by a half a percent; but also
to try to spark job creation in the private sector more.  The
plan passed the House.  It has the support of a majority of the
Senate.  At the present time
column2: all the Republican   senators as a

column1: bloc are filibustering the bill.  That is
to a vote.
I believe that Senator Specter would like to vote
for the bill.  And I believe that Senator Dole
leader
column2: has put a lot of pressure on a lot of the Republicans to

column1: stay hitched.  And they're all saying that this bill increases
the deficit.  It doesn't.  This bill is well below the spending
targets that Congress approved
this year.  This bill is paid for by budget cuts in the next five
years.  This bill is designed to give a jump-start to the
economy.  And I must say
column2: a lot of the Republican senators that

column1: are holding it up
billions of dollars of emergency spending of just this kind --
much of it was totally unrelated to creating jobs.
So what I'm trying to do is to break this logjam.
I've held out an olive branch
column2: I've offered a compromise.  But I

column1: think that we ought to try to put some more Americans to work
right now to show that we're changing the direction of the
country.  And that's the purpose of the bill.
Q	  Have you been in touch with Senator Specter or
his office lately?
THE PRESIDENT:  Well
regularly to -- through my White House Congressional Liaison
operation to the senators that we think are open to this --
Senator Specter
from Vermont
others whom we believe know we need more jobs in this economy and
know that we are paying for this with budget cuts over the life
of the budget I presented.
You know
column2: it has a lot of appeal to say

column1: got a big deficit
column2: we shouldn't increase it more.  But the truth

column1: is that we are paying for this with budget cuts in the whole life
of the budget over the next few years.  And more importantly
have this program well below the spending targets that Congress
has already approved for this year.  And they've done this for
years
column2: with the Republicans voting for it -- many Republicans

column1: voting for it -- for things that weren't nearly as important as
putting the American people back to work.
So I just hope that this doesn't become a political
issue.  It ought to just be about the people of this country and
the need for jobs.
Q	  I have some questions from people who supported
you
column2: and some people who are skeptical about your administration.

column1: It has to do with their hopes
column2: and also with their fears.  A lot

column1: of people who supported you and voted for you in Pennsylvania --I
think some of them are now saying
column2: we're glad we got him in the

column1: White House
column2: but now look at this incredible process he has to go

column1: through.  Look at these problems.  Look at this gridlock.  And
they're beginning to wonder
column2: is this going to work; can you pull

column1: it off?  And
it was going to be like this.
THE PRESIDENT:  Well
people
very fast.  The budget resolution that the Congress passed is the
fastest they have ever passed a budget resolution -- ever -- in
history
column2: setting out the next five-year budget targets.  So we

column1: are moving really rapidly.  And we've got them working on
political reform
wide range of things.
But it's a big operation.  You can't expect to turn
it around overnight.  It took 12 years to produce the conditions
which led to the victory I received from the people in November
and we can't turn it around in 90 days.  But I think we're making
real
I would urge the people not to get discouraged.
We're not going to win every battle
to happen overnight.  But we are definitely moving and changing
things.
Q	  Thank you very much.
The President of the United States
here live at Pittsburgh International Airport.  I'm Mike Whitely
KDKA News."

Actually
column2: fossil fuel plants run hotter than the usual

column1: boiling-water reactor nuclear plants.  (There's a gripe in the industry
that nuclear power uses 1900 vintage steam technology).  So it's
more important in nuclear plants to get the cold end of the system
as cold as possible.  Hence big cooling towers.
Oil and gas fired steam plants also have condensers
usually are sized to get the steam back into hot water
way down to ambient.  Some plants do cool the condensers with water
rather than air; as one Canadian official
pollution"" de-icing a river
column4: we view heat as a resource"".

column1: Everybody runs closed-cycle boilers.  The water used is
purified of solids
column2: which otherwise crud up the boiler plumbing when

column1: the water boils.  Purifying water for boiler use is a bigger job than
cooling it
column2: so the boiler water is recycled."

column1: 1441|"THE WHITE HOUSE
Office of the Press Secretary
For Immediate Release                             April 15
REMARKS BY THE PRESIDENT
TO LAW ENFORCEMENT ORGANIZATIONS
The Rose Garden
2:52 P.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT:  Good afternoon.  Ladies and gentlemen
two months ago I presented a comprehensive plan to reduce our
national deficit and to increase our investment in the American
people
column2: their jobs and their economic future.  The federal budget

column1: plan passed Congress in record time
column2: and created a new sense of hope

column1: and opportunity in the country.
Then
column2: the short-term jobs plan I presented to Congress

column1: which would create a half a million jobs in the next two years passed
the House of Representatives two weeks ago.  It now has the support
of a majority of the United States Senate.
All of these members of Congress know it's time to get
the economy moving again
column2: to get job growth going again

column1: fast start on the investments we need to build a lasting prosperity.
Unfortunately
column2: a minority of the members of the United States Senate

column1: have used gridlock tactics to prevent their colleagues from working
the will of the majority on the jobs bill.
When Congress returns
column2: I ask every senator from every

column1: state and from both parties to remember what is at stake.  The issue
is not politics
column2: it's people.  Sixteen million of them are looking

column1: for full-time jobs and can't find them.  These men and women don't
care about who's up or down in Washington.  They care about paying
the rent and meeting the mortgage payment
table and buying shoes for their children
dignity that comes from doing a day's work and supporting their
families and drawing a paycheck.
They're asking those of us who have the privilege of
serving to put aside politics and do something now to move our
economy forward.  I am prepared to do that.  And I have been working
with the Senate to come up with an adjusted package that meets some
of the concerns of those who have been blocking action on the jobs
plan.  I'm willing to compromise
column2: so long as we keep the focus on

column1: jobs
column2: keep the focus on growth and keep the focus on meeting unmet

column1: national needs.
Our opponents have been asking for a smaller package.
Today I ask them to join me in determining exactly what kind and what
size package Congress can approve that actually meets the needs of
the American people.
But even as we make those reductions and the package
will be smaller
column2: I believe we must address problems that are on the

column1: minds of millions of Americans
the need to toughen law enforcement in our society to deal with the
dramatic rise in violent crime.
So I will ask
additional $200 million in federal funding to help local communities
to rehire police officers who have been laid off because of the
fiscal problems caused by the national recession.  Together
matching effort by local governments
column2: this could put as many as
000 police officers back on the job
column3: and back on the beat in

column1: communities all across our nation.
At a time when too many of our people live in fear of
violent crime
column2: when too many businesses have closed and too many

column1: people have lost their jobs because people are afraid to leave their
homes
column2: rehiring thousands of officers is one of the best investments

column1: America can make.  And I ask both Houses of Congress to make that
investment in our people's safety and in their piece of mind.
I believe in the need for strong federal action to keep
the economy going toward recovery and to create jobs.  Make no
mistake about it:  I will fight for these priorities as hard as I
ever have.  I will never forget that the people sent me here to fight
for their jobs
column2: their future and for fundamental change.

column1: I want to thank the police officers who are here today
and tell you that not a single one of them knew before they came here
that I had determined to ask for more money in this jobs bill to
rehire police officers.  They came here because they believe in the
summer jobs portion of the package.  And I want them to be free to
talk about that.  They came here not out of any law enforcement
concern other than the fact that they wanted the kids in this country
to have a chance to have jobs this summer
a brighter and more peaceful future.
I say what I say today not just because it's good for
law enforcement but because it's good for the people who live in
these communities.  I have always supported community policing not
only because it helps to prevent crime and to lower the crime rate
but because it cements better relationships between people in law
enforcement and the people that they're hired to protect.  It reduces
the chances of abusive action by police officers and increases the
chances of harmony and safe streets at the same time.
These are the kinds of things that we are trying to do.
I promised in my campaign that I'd do everything I could to put
another 100
column2: 000 police officers on the street over the next four

column1: years.  This makes a good downpayment on that.  This keeps in mind
the core of the jobs package.  And this will help us to move forward.
So I ask the people in the Senate who have blocked the
jobs bill
column2: let's work together.  I can accept a reduced package if

column1: you will increase your commitment to safe streets.  I do not accept
the fact that we should reduce our commitment to summer jobs or to
building our infrastructure or to doing those other things that will
create real and lasting  prosperity for our people.  I have done my

Attorney General.
Q	  Mr. President
column2: can you tell us -- do you think that

column1: the jobs package could be put in further jeopardy by controversy over
the suggestion of a VAT tax at this point in the congressional
dialogue?
THE PRESIDENT:  Not at all.  I think it should have --
they wouldn't have any relationship one to the other.  First of all
I made absolutely no decision on that.  You should know that there's
a lot of support in the business community and the labor community --
people have asked us to consider that because of the enormous burden
of the present system on many of our major employers
many of those that we depend upon to generate jobs and to carry the
strength of this economy.  But I have made absolutely no decision
that would even approach that on that or any other kind of general
tax.
Q	  Do you personally believe that the American public
is ready to pay for -- to have another tax to pay for health care?  I
mean
column2: apart from what business and labor leaders have said --

column1: THE PRESIDENT:  I'm not going to speculate on that.  I
will say this:  The real issue is how quickly we can recycle the
benefits of all the savings to cover the cost.  I mean
everyone knows that if you do what we're proposing to do
streamline the insurance system
column2: if you fix the system so that

column1: there's no longer an enormous economic incentive to over-utilize or
over-provide certain services
column2: if you provide primary and preventive

column1: care in places where it isn't now
absolutely massive savings to the health care system.
The real question is whether you can transfer those
savings to cover those who have no coverage now or those who have
virtually no coverage so that you provide people the security.  I
have no idea.  The polls say that
column2: but I don't know.  All I know is

column1: the polls that I see in the press that many of you have commissioned
they say overwhelmingly the American people want the security of an
affordable health care system.
But I don't think that has anything to do with this
stimulus
column2: and it certainly shouldn't have.  People want a job first

column1: and foremost.  They want that more than anything else.

column2: can you tell us what parts of

column1: your package you consider vital and uncompromisable?  I assume summer

THE PRESIDENT:  I want the summer jobs; I want the

bill
column2: which did not pass the Congress last year.  This is a

column1: supplement to that
column2: not a substitute for it in any way.  But I think

with AIDS.  And there are several other things that I think should be

There are a number of other things that I don't -- I
don't think any of it should be cut
Mitchell and Senator Byrd -- I talked to them.  And Senator Dole

to begin a turn.

torque which twists the bike over.

1517|Archive-name: atheism/overview
Alt-atheism-archive-name: overview
Last-modified: 5 April 1993
Version: 1.2
Overview
Welcome to alt.atheism and alt.atheism.moderated.
This is the first in a series of regular postings aimed at new readers of the
newsgroups.
Many groups of a 'controversial' nature have noticed that new readers often
come up with the same questions
them to the net.  In addition
column2: people often request information which has

column1: been posted time and time again.  In order to try and cut down on this
alt.atheism groups have a series of five regular postings under the following
titles:
1.  Alt.Atheism FAQ: Overview for New Readers
2.  Alt.Atheism FAQ: Introduction to Atheism
3.  Alt.Atheism FAQ: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
4.  Alt.Atheism FAQ: Constructing a Logical Argument
5.  Alt.Atheism FAQ: Atheist Resources
This is article number 1.  Please read numbers 2 and 3 before posting.  The
others are entirely optional.
If you are new to Usenet
column2: you may also find it helpful to read the newsgroup

column1: news.announce.newusers.  The articles titled ""A Primer on How to Work With
the Usenet Community""
column2: ""Answers to Frequently Asked Questions about Usenet""

column1: and ""Hints on writing style for Usenet"" are particularly relevant.  Questions
concerning how news works are best asked in news.newusers.questions.
If you are unable to find any of the articles listed above
Stuff"" section below.

readers of alt.atheism and alt.atheism.moderated.  In particular
thank the following people:
