These articles are free.  Truly free.  You may copy them and distribute them
to anyone you wish.  However
column2: please send any changes or corrections to the

column1: author
column2: and please do not re-post copies of the articles to alt.atheism; it

column1: does nobody any good to have multiple versions of the same document floating
around the network.
Finding Stuff
All of the FAQ files *should* be somewhere on your news system.  Here are
some suggestions on what to do if you can't find them:
1. Check the newsgroup alt.atheism.  Look for subject lines starting with
""Alt.Atheism FAQ:"".
2. Check the newsgroup news.answers for the same subject lines.
If you don't find anything in steps 1 or 2
column2: your news system isn't set up

column1: correctly
column2: and you may wish to tell your system administrator about the

column1: problem.
3. If you have anonymous FTP access
Go to the directory /pub/usenet/alt.atheism
versions of the FAQ files there.
FTP is a a way of copying files between networked computers.  If you
need help in using or getting started with FTP
mail-server@rtfm.mit.edu with
send usenet/news.answers/ftp-list/faq
in the body.
4. There are other sites which also carry news.answers postings.  The article
""Introduction to the news.answers newsgroup"" carries a list of these
sites; the article is posted regularly to news.answers.
5. If you don't have FTP
consisting of the following lines:
send usenet/news.answers/finding-sources
send usenet/alt.atheism/faq
send usenet/alt.atheism/introduction
send usenet/alt.atheism/logic
send usenet/alt.atheism/resources
5. (Penultimate resort)  Send mail to mail-server@mantis.co.uk consisting of
the following lines:
send atheism/faq/faq.txt
send atheism/faq/logic.txt
send atheism/faq/intro.txt
send atheism/faq/resource.txt
and our poor overworked modems will try and send you a copy of the files.
There's other stuff
column2: too; interesting commands to try are ""help"" and

column1: ""send atheism/index"".
6. (Last resort)  Mail mathew@mantis.co.uk
column2: or post an article to the

column1: newsgroup asking how you can get the FAQ files.  You should only do this
if you've tried the above methods and they've failed; it's not nice to
clutter the newsgroup or people's mailboxes with requests for files.
it's better than posting without reading the FAQ
people whose email addresses get mangled in transit and who don't have
FTP will probably need assistance obtaining the FAQ files.
The actual hourglass is hollow and is designed to generate a draft
exploiting the venturi effect.  Around the base of the hourglass is a
ring of water towers.  Warm river water
in the plant
column2: is sprayed over louvres.  The draft being pulled through

column1: the tower cools the water by both evaporation and convection.  The
sensible heat extracted from the cooling water is the driving force for
draft generation.
It should be noted that the hourglass-shaped cooling towers are used on
both fossile and nuclear plants.  It should also be noted that at
locations where water is plentiful
column2: the cooling towers are only used part

column1: time
column2: when the discharge temperature would exceed some release limit.

column1: It was once thought that the warm discharge water was damaging to fish.
Fishermen know that is thoroughly incorrect.  Nontheless
usually state
column2: regulations remain in some instances.  Since it typically

column1: takes 60
column2: 000 hp worth of pumping to move the volume of water needed

column1: to cool a 1000 MWe plant
column2: the cost of using the towers is not insignificant."

Getting rid of the keys is actually pretty easy to do automatically on
a communications link
column2: as opposed to storage where the keys have to be

column1: retained somehow as long as the owner wants to be able to retrieve the
data.
The right way to do communications security is to generate a random
session key with Diffie Hellman
column2: use it for a while and then destroy

column1: it. Once it's gone
recordings of the conversation.
To make sure you aren't being attacked by a man in the middle
have to authenticate your DH exchanges. The AT&T secure phone does
this by displaying the DH key so you can compare them verbally over
the phone. This is nice and simple
column2: but it relies on user awareness

column1: plus the inability of the man in the middle to duplicate the users'
voices.
A better way is to authenticate the exchanges with RSA. Since you'd
never use RSA for actual encryption
would only allow someone to impersonate you in a future conversation
and even that only until you revoke your public key.  They would still
not be able to decrypt recordings of prior conversations for which the
session keys have been destroyed.
I'm convinced that this is how the government's own secure phones
(the STU-III) must work. Neat

CRYPTO '93  -  Conference Announcement & Final Call for Papers
The Thirteenth Annual CRYPTO Conference
Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR)
the IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Security and Privacy
the Computer Science Department of the University of California
Barbara
column2: and Bell-Northern Research (a subsidiary of Northern Telecom)

column1: will be held on the campus of the University of California
on August 22-26
column2: 1993. Original research papers and technical expository talks

column1: are solicited on all practical and theoretical aspects of cryptology. It is
anticipated that some talks may also be presented by special invitation of the
Program Committee.
INSTRUCTIONS FOR AUTHORS:  Authors are requested to send 12 copies of a
detailed abstract (not a full paper) by April 26
at the address given below. A limit of 10 pages of 12pt type (not counting
the bibliography or the title page) is placed on all submissions. Submissions
must arrive on time or be postmarked no later than April 21
airmail in order to receive consideration by the Program Committee. It is
required that submissions start with a succinct statement of the problem
addressed
appropriate for a non-specialist reader. Technical development directed to
the specialist should follow as needed.
Abstracts that have been submitted to other conferences that have proceedings
are NOT eligible for submission.
Submissions MUST BE ANONYMOUS. This means that names and affiliations of
authors should only appear on the title page of the submission; it should
be possible to remove this page and send the papers to Program Committee
members. A Latex style file that produces output in this format is available by email from the Program Chair.
Authors will be informed of acceptance or rejection in a letter mailed on
or before June 21
column2: 1993. A compilation of all accepted abstracts will be

column1: available at the conference in the form of pre-proceedings. Authors of
accepted abstracts will be allowed to submit revised versions for the
pre-proceedings. A revised abstract should contain only minor changes and
corrections to the originally submitted abstract. All revised abstracts must
be received by the Program Chair by July 16
STRICTLY ENFORCED for the pre-proceedings.
Complete conference proceedings are expected to be published in Springer-
Verlag's Lecture Notes in Computer Science series at a later date
negotiation.

1544|To following up my own note:
: : It looks like everything works as advertised but I am disappointed
: : with the speed.  I'm using an Intel 400 internal 14.4k modem in the PC
: : with Telebit 14.4k on the Unix end
: : 19.2Kbits by the Unix com link. To get a quantitative comparison
: : did 'cat file' where ""file"" is 20 kbyte uncompressed ascii text
: : it took 75 seconds to scroll through an X window over the modem link
: : 270 chars/sec.  Using the identical hardware and Procomm+FW the same
: : ""cat file' takes 11 seconds
: : on my PC at work (HP) every day for the same Unix access from a PC over
: : a LAN and like that just fine.  The same 'cat file' scrolls by in
: : ~2 seconds on the LAN connection.
I just tried a few experiments. I cat'd a 20261-byte file (471 lines)
under various scenarios:
PC-Xview for DOS in a full-screen OS/2 window (1024x768x16):    18 sec
Telix (DOS) in an OS/2 window (1024xs768x256):                  107 sec!
Telix (DOS) is a full-screen OS/2 window (standard VGA):        11 sec
Telix (DOS) in a Windows 3.1 window (1024x768x256):             30 sec
UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window (1024x768x256):        gave up after 4 min!
UW/WIN in Windows 3.1 (1024x768x256):           faster
UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window using pg       30 sec
little faster (I had to keep
hitting the space bar)
I was using an ATI Wonder XL video card
So PC-Xview for DOS looks pretty good (and the line-by-line scrolling
in OS/2 desktop looks pathetic
good).
I tried it under PC-Xview using my normal (9x15bold or 10x20) font
and with a very small font
column2: and there was no difference in the times.

bottleneck was the 9600-baud modem

> I use Emacs and I want to customize my keyboard better.
> When I set up stuff in my .emacs with a keymap and define-keys
> I can only access certain of the keys on my X-Terminal's
> keyboard. I can't get e.g. F10
> seem to have either the same or no keycode. I have a feeling
> this can't be fixed in emacs itself
column2: but that I need to do some

column1: > xmodmap stuff. Can someone help me?
Unfortunately
column2: the key event handling is pretty much hardwired into

column1: emacs.  I ran into this problem a while back; my solution was to
change the source code so that all of these special keys generated
character sequences which basically encoded the keysym and modifier
state as escape sequences -- for example
would indicate that the ""HOME"" key was pressed
down.  You could also detect standard keys with odd modifiers
as ""shift-Return"".
If anybody wants these changes
have to have the source available and be comfortable munging with
it a bit.  Basically you have to replace the keypress handling code
in the source file ""x11term.c"".  Maybe if someone at OSF is
interested
column2: I can send them the tweaks

column1: bigger fish to fry (hopefully including the much talked about
emacs V19!).  If there's sufficient interest
somewhere
column2: although this probably isn't the appropriate group for it.

column1: Notes:
* This special code will only apply if you let emacs create
its own (X11) window.  If you run it in plain old tty mode (which
includes Xterm windows) then it's business as usual.
* The patches I made were to version 18.58
[I also did this a while back under HP-UX].  The patches are
in a chunk of code between '#if sun ... #endif' but could
easily be adapted for anything else.

INTENSIVE JAPANESE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH THIS SUMMER
The University of Pittsburgh is offering two intensive Japanese language
courses this summer.  Both courses
Intensive Intermediate Japanese
each equivalent to one full year of Japanese language study.  They begin
June 7 and end August 13.  The courses meet five days per week
per day.  There is a flat rate tuition charge of $1600 per course.
Fellowships available for science and engineering students.  Contact
Steven Brener
column2: Program Manager of the Japanese Science and Technology

column1: Management Program
column2: at the University of Pittsburgh at the number or

column1: address below.
ALL INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY
UNIVERSITY STUDENTS.
JAPANESE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
The Japanese Science and Technology Management Program (JSTMP) is a new
program jointly developed by the University of Pittsbugh and Carnegie Mellon
University.  Students and professionals in the engineering and scientific
communitites are encouraged to apply for classes commencing in June 1993 and
January 1994.
PROGRAM OBJECTIVES
The program intends to promote technology transfer between Japan and the
United States.  It is also designed to let scientists
experience how the Japanese proceed with technological development.  This is
facilitated by extended internships in Japanese research facilities and
laboratories that provide participants with the opportunity to develop
long-term professional relationships with their Japanese counterparts.
PROGRAM DESIGN
To fulfill the objectives of the program
develop advanced language capability and a deep understanding of Japan and
its culture.  Correspondingly
column2: JSTMP consists of three major components:

column1: 1. TRAINING IN THE JAPANESE LANGUAGE
Several Japanese language courses will be offered
designed to expedite language preparation for scientists and engineers in a
relatively short time.
2. EDUCATION IN JAPANESE BUSINESS AND SOCIAL CULTURE
A particular enphasis is placed on attaining a deep understanding of the
cultural and educational basis of Japanese management approaches in
manufacturing and information technology.  Courses will be available in a
variety of departments throughout both universities including Anthropology
Sociology
will be conducted.  Further
column2: a field trip to Japanese manufacturing or

column1: research facilities in the United States will be scheduled.
3. AN INTERNSHIP OR A STUDY MISSION IN JAPAN
Upon completion of their language and cultural training at PITT and CMU
participants will have the opportunity to go to Japan and observe
and participate in the management of technology.  Internships in Japan
will generally run for one year; however
FELLOWSHIPS COVERING TUITION FOR LANGUAGE AND CULTURE COURSES
STIPENDS FOR LIVING EXPENSES ARE AVAILABLE.
FOR MORE INFORMATION AND APPLICATION MATERIALS CONTACT
STEVEN BRENER				SUSIE BROWN
JSTMP					Carnegie Mellon University
University of Pittsburgh		Pittsburgh

Here's how I understand it. Remember from stellar evolution that
black holes and neutron stars(pulsars) are formed from high mass stars
M(star)=1.4M(sun).  High mass stars live fast and burn hard
appoximately 10^5-10^7 years before going nova
they don't live long enough to get perturbed out of the galactic plane

presidential campaign that I spent the first week of 1970 alone
in Moscow and did not return again until three days before Mr.

when we could be genuine partners.  So I have always had a
personal feeling about Russia.

had the chance to
column2: I could play a role in seeing our two

1583|"I recently published a new privacy-protecting off-line electronic cash
system as a technical report at CWI. Being a PhD-student at David
Chaum's cryptography-group
column2: our group has a long history in research

column1: in the field of privacy-protecting cash systems.
The report is called CS-R9323.ps.Z
retrieved from
from the directory pub/CWIreports/AA.
The postscript-file is suitable for 300dpi laserprinters.
ABSTRACT (from coverpage): We present a new off-line electronic cash
system based on a problem
little use has been made in literature thus far. Our system is the
first to be based entirely on discrete logarithms.  Using the
representation problem as a basic concept
introduced that enable us to construct protocols for withdrawal and
payment that do not use the cut and choose methodology of earlier
systems. As a consequence
column2: our cash system is much more efficient in

column1: both computation and communication complexity than any such system
proposed previously.
Another important aspect of our system concerns its provability.
Contrary to previously proposed systems
mathematically proven to a very great extent. Specifically
make one plausible assumption concerning a single hash-function
ability to break the system seems to imply that one can break the
Diffie-Hellman problem.
Our system offers a number of extensions that are hard to achieve in
previously known systems. In our opinion the most interesting of these
is that the entire cash system (including all the extensions) can be
incorporated in a setting based on wallets with observers
the important advantage that double-spending can be prevented in the
first place
column2: rather than detecting the identity of a double-spender

column1: after the fact. In particular
column2: it can be incorporated even under the

column1: most stringent requirements conceivable about the privacy of the user
which seems to be impossible to do with previously proposed systems.
Another benefit of our system is that framing attempts by a bank have
negligible probability of success (independent of computing power) by
a simple mechanism from within the system
previous solutions lack entirely. Furthermore
can be extended to checks
retaining its computational efficiency.
Cryptographers are challenged to try to break this system!
I made a particular effort to keep the report as self-contained as
possible.  Nevertheless
me and I will try to reply as good as I can. Any comments are also
welcome!
Stefan Brands

you may not be able to later.  This isn't a case of reaching over and
flipping a switch; much of the spacecraft has to be working correctly
to execute a ""turn off"" command successfully.  Spacecraft do malfunction
in their old age.  The big concern is not radio clutter from idle
spacecraft

Unfortunately
column2: Hep B infection can eventuate in chronic hepatitis and

column1: subsequent cirrhosis.  Although not many patients with Hep B go on to
chronic hepatitis
column2: it does still occur in a good number (20%?) and is

column1: something to keep in mind.  Hepatitis C (was: non-A
more frequently leads to chronic hep and cirrhosis.  There is also an
autimmune chronic hepatitis that affects mostly younger women which
also leads to cirrhosis.
Of course
column2: cirrhosis is a most unkind disease.  The most dangerous

column1: effects relate to portal hypertension and loss of liver function.
Patients develop life-threatening variceal bleeds and hepatic comas
among many other problems
column2: as a result of disturbances in hepatic

column1: circulation.  Less ominously
column2: they can exhibit the effects of

column1: hyperestrogenemia which often characterize patients with cirrhosis.
These effects include telangiactasias (small red skin lesions) and
men
column2: gynecomastia (breast development).  The only real treatment for

column1: cirrhosis is liver transplant.
Keep in mind that cirrhosis is not expected
your friend's case.  Nevertheless you might want to bring up the
subject of chronic disease and cirrhosis with the doctor.  Hopefully he
or she can then carefully explain these sequelae of Hep B infection to
you

column2: CA (API) -- A tense stand-off entered its third week

column1: today as authorities reported no progress in negotiations with
charismatic cult leader Steve Jobs.
Negotiators are uncertain of the situation inside the compound
some reports suggest that half of the hundreds of followers inside
have been terminated.  Others claim to be staying of their own free
will
column2: but Jobs' persuasive manner makes this hard to confirm.

column1: In conversations with authorities
information on how heavily prepared the group is for war with the
industry.  At times
column2: he has claimed to ""have hardware which will blow

column1: anything else away""
column2: while more recently he claims they have stopped

column1: manufacturing their own.
Agents from the ATF (Apple-Taligent Forces) believe that the group is
equipped with serious hardware
possibly Canon equipment.
The siege has attracted a variety of spectators
other cultists.  Some have offered to intercede in negotiations
including a young man who will identify himself only as ""Bill"" and
claims to be the ""MS-iah"".
Former members of the cult
hesitantly of their former lives
20-hour days
column2: and subsisting on Jolt and Twinkies.  There were

column1: frequent lectures in which they were indoctrinated into a theory of
interpersonal computing"" which rejects traditional roles.
Late-night vigils on Chesapeake Drive are taking their toll on
federal marshals.  Loud rock and roll
throughout the night.  Some fear that Jobs will fulfill his own
apocalyptic prophecies
column2: a worry reinforced when the loudspeakers

column1: carry Jobs' own speeches -- typically beginning with a chilling ""I
want to welcome you to the 'Next World' ""."
Now why would anyone ""post"" anything encrypted? Encryption is only of
use between persons who know how to decrypt the data.
And why should I care what other people look at?
What does concern me is the continued erosion of my constitutional
rights. ( Amendments I
column4: and V to note a few. )

column2: this is also my understanding of the majority of Islamic laws.

column1: However
column2: I believe there are also certain legal rulings which

column1: five schools of law (4 sunni and 1 jaffari)
muslim or non-muslims
column2: both within and outside dar-al-islam. I do

column1: not know if apostasy (when accompanied by active
open hostility to Islam) falls into this category of the law. I do know
that
historically
column2: apostasy has very rarely been punished at all

column1: by the death penalty.
My understanding is that Khomeini's ruling was not based on the
law of apostasy (alone). It was well known that Rushdie was an apostate
long before he wrote the offending novel and certainly there is no
precedent in the Qur'an
column3: or in Islamic history for indiscriminantly

column1: levelling death penalties for apostasy.
I believe the charge levelled against Rushdie was that of ""fasad"". This
ruling applies both within and outside the domain of an
Islamic state and it can be carried out by individuals. The reward was
not offered by Khomeini but by individuals within Iran.
I would concur that the thrust of the fatwa (from what I remember) was
levelled at the author and all those who assisted in the publication
of the book. However
column2: the charge of ""fasad"" can encompass a

column1: number of lesser charges. I remember that when diplomatic relations
broke off between Britain and Iran over the fatwa - Iran stressed that
the condemnation of the author
column2: and the removal of the book from

column1: circulation were two preliminary conditions for resolving the
crisis"". But you are correct to point out that banning the book was not
the main thrust behind the fatwa. Islamic charges such as fasad are
levelled at people
The Rushdie situation was followed in Iran for several months before the
issuance of the fatwa. Rushdie went on a media blitz
presenting himself as a lone knight guarding the sacred values of
secular democracy and mocking the foolish concerns of people
crazy enough to actually hold their religious beliefs as sacred.
Fanning the flames and milking the controversy to boost
his image and push the book
column2: he was everywhere in the media. Then

column1: Muslim demonstrators in several countries were killed while
protesting against the book. Rushdie appeared momentarily
concerned
column2: then climbed back on his media horse to once again

column1: attack the Muslims and defend his sacred rights. It was at this
point that the fatwa on ""fasad"" was issued.
The fatwa was levelled at the person of Rushdie - any actions of
Rushdie that feed the situation contribute to the legitimization of
the ruling. The book remains in circulation not by some independant
will of its own but by the will of the author and the publishers. The fatwa
against the person of Rushdie encompasses his actions as well. The
crime was certainly a crime in progress (at many levels) and was being
played out (and played up) in the the full view of the media."

column1: While I don't mean to damn Henrik's attempt to be helpful here
he's using a common misconception that should be corrected.
Mach banding will occur for any image.  It is not the color
quantization you see when you don't have enough bits.  It is the
human eye's response to transitions or edges between intensities.
The result is that colors near the transistion look brighter on
the brighter side and darker on the darker side.
--Andre

NAVY SCIENTIFIC VISUALIZATION AND VIRTUAL REALITY SEMINAR
Tuesday

(formerly the David Taylor Research Center)
Bethesda
SPONSOR: NESS (Navy Engineering Software System) is sponsoring a
one-day Navy Scientific Visualization and Virtual Reality Seminar.
The purpose of the seminar is to present and exchange information for
Navy-related scientific visualization and virtual reality programs
research
PRESENTATIONS: Presentations are solicited on all aspects of
Navy-related scientific visualization and virtual reality.  All
current work
organizations will be considered.  Four types of presentations are
available.
1. Regular presentation: 20-30 minutes in length
2. Short presentation: 10 minutes in length
3. Video presentation: a stand-alone videotape (author need not
attend the seminar)
4. Scientific visualization or virtual reality demonstration (BYOH)
Accepted presentations will not be published in any proceedings
however
column2: viewgraphs and other materials will be reproduced for

column1: seminar attendees.

Authors should include the type of presentation
addresses
papers should designate one point of contact.

Notification of acceptance will be sent by May 14
Materials for reproduction must be received by June 1

"" ...  The alternative approach (to CISC)
which has been adopted by many in
recent years
column2: has come to be known as ""RISC"": the Reduced

column1: Instruction Set Computer.  This can be characterised simply as
""Simpler is Faster""; by simplifying the design (e.g.  by reducing
the variety of instructions & addressing modes)
designed to run faster.  Even at the cost of needing more
instructions
column2: the same task can be done more quickly by the simpler

column1: faster design.
A typical RISC processor will:
o provide a large number of registers (e.g.  32);
o perform all data operations on registers;
o provide few addressing modes (e.g. immediate or 'register + offset');
o only allow load & store operations to access memory;
o only use a few instruction formats;
o only support a few data types (e.g. integer

column1: 1734|: I would like to get your opinions on this: when exactly does an engaged
: couple become ""married"" in God's eyes?  Some say that if the two have
: publically announced their plans to marry
column2: have made their vows to God

column1: : are unswervingly committed to one another (I realize this is a subjective
: qualifier) they are married/joined in God's sight.
The way I read Scripture
column2: a couple becomes married when they are *physically*

column1: married
column2: i.e. when they first have sexual intercourse.

column1: e.g. the end of Genesis 2 (quoted from memory) ``for this reason
leave his parents and be joined to his wife
column2: and they will become one flesh''

column1: (Jesus also quotes this scripture referring to marriage).
If you read through Genesis in particular
column2: you will often come across the

column1: phraseology: ``[man] lay with [woman]
column2: and she became his wife''. This

column1: implies that she became his wife when they lay together
point of intercourse.
Compare this with Jewish tradition: Joseph
was pregnant
column2: had it in mind to divorce her quietly -- but Mary and Joseph were

column1: *betrothed*
column3: they were in a binding relationship (which

column1: required a divorce to get out of)
column2: but *marriage* would not occur until Mary

column1: and Joseph went to bed together.
Compare with Christ and the Church (Ephesians 5
described as the ``bride'' of Christ
column2: but the *marriage* of the Lamb takes

column1: place when Jesus returns. i.e.
column2: we are in a binding love-relationship with

column1: Jesus
column2: but we are still looking forward to the time when the marriage will

column1: take place. I see this as the spiritual equivalent of sexual intercourse
because it represents the most intimate fellowship possible between man and God.
In summary
column2: engagement should be honoured as a binding relationship

column1: not marriage. A civil ceremony is not marriage either. Marriage occurs at the
point when the betrothed couple go to bed together. (I don't mean to demean the
civil or church ceremony -- ours was great! I don't mean to be too pedantic.)
Historically
column2: I think I am correct in stating that the civil ceremony (i.e. a

column1: marriage recognised by the state)
column2: has only been around in the West since

column1: Napoleon
column2: who introduced it to keep tabs on the people (although I'm ready to be

column1: corrected on that point!)
This view obviously raises some questions:
What about those who have had sex with one or more partners
marriage. Are those people also ``married''?
If it is true that marriage occurs at the point of intercourse
to be married in the eyes of the state? (I would say Yes
the laws of our nations in the West. Although it is not illegal to sleep
together though unmarried in most Western countries
column2: I believe that it is God-

column1: honouring to proclaim our marriage to the state and to our friends before
actually consummating our marriage. Its to do with our being salt and light
also to do with how people will perceive us; i.e. it is culturally insensitive
to declare yourself married without going through a civil ceremony.)
Michael Davis (cs89mcd@brunel.ac.uk)"

1773|One of the candidates that has been suggested for a key registration
body is the ACLU.  I think this is poor choice.   The ACLU is

liberties are administered.  Traditionally
column2: auditors do not like to get

column1: involved in the design or operational aspects of things
reason.
When I was a systems programmer
column2: it always infuriated me that the

column1: auditors would come in and tell us our implementation stunk from a
security point of view
column2: but wouldn't tell us how to fix it.  I always

column1: figured they just liked to critcize
column2: without doing the work to help fix

column1: the problem.
Then I took a stint as an auditor
column2: and I found out the real reason.

column1: Auditors don't like to recommend solutions
column2: because it puts them in a

column1: bad position if they have to criticize the implementation later.  The
auditee can say
column3: you told us this way would be OK.""  It

column1: compromises the independence that is a necessary part of the auditor's
job.
Taking the case at hand
column2: suppose ACLU becomes a key half registrar.

column1: Suppose that
column2: perhaps through some error on ACLU's part

column1: away that shouldn't
column2: and is used to deprive someone of her civil

column1: liberties.  The ACLU gets wind of this
column2: and wants to take it to court.

column1: But they end up being at the same time on the side of the defendant
and of the plaintiff
column2: which is not an easy position to be in.

column1: There are exceptions to the complete independence of auditors: at one
place where I worked
automatically by a signature drum on the bursting machine.  This drum
was kept by the auditors (who also kept the check stock)
was brought down to Data Processing when it was time to do the checks.
I believe the difference between this situation and the key registration
situation is that it is fairly obvious when it is time to do the payroll
checks:  if they were done yesterday
column2: and someone wants to do them again

column1: today
column2: he better be able to produce yesterday's checks so that they can

column1: be destroyed.  Determining which of the many requests for key halves are

Since the Mac uses ONLY SCSI-1 for hard drives YES the ""figure includes a
hundred $$$ for SCSI drivers""  This is sloppy people and DUMB.
Ok once again with the SCSI spec list:
SCSI-1 {with a SCSI-1 controler chip} synchronous range is indeed 0-5MB/s
asynchronous range is slower at 0-3MB/s.
SCSI-1 {With a SCSI-2 controller chip}: 4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst {8-bit}
Note the INCREASE in SPEED
column2: the Mac Quadra uses this version of SCSI-1

column1: so it DOES exist. Some PCs use this set up too.
SCSI-2 {8-bit/SCSI-1 mode}:          4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst
{for those who want SCSI-2 but don't want to pay for the 16-bit or 32-bit
hardware or mess with the SCSI-2 software controllers.  Usable by SCSI-1
devices with close to 8-bit SCSI-2 speeds}
SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst
SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst
On the other interfaces let DXB132@psuvm.psu.edu speak:
Again synchronous and asynchronous modes with asynchronous much slower
{Range 0-5MB/s}
One problem is the inconsitant use of the term 'SCSI' in articles and by
people.  Its PROPER meaning is ""The set of SCSI interfaces composed of
SCSI-1 AND SCSI-2""
Look at the inconsitant use of SCSI in the below quote:
(My comments in {})
PC Magazine April 27
column2: 1993:29 ""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI

column1: {This is asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip} 20% faster than IDE...""
{this is BOTH asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip AND 8-bit SCSI-2}
To read CONSITANTLY the quote SHOULD read:
{asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip}
Although asynchronous SCSI-1 is twice as fast as ESDI
speed of IDE...""
or {asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip or 8-bit SCSI-2}
Although SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip and 8-bit SCSI-2 are eight times as fast as
ESDI
NOTE the NONUSE of 'SCSI' by itself.  This eliminates ambaguity.
SCSI-1 drivers are somewhat reasonable while 16-bit and 32-bit SCSI-2 drivers
are VERY expansive {8-bit SCSI-2 can use SCSI-1 drivers with little speed
degridation(the Mac Quadra does EXACTLY this.)}"

column2: I have been getting a lot of requests for this information so I thought

column1: I would post it for those interested parties. (Sorry for length).
To increase the MacIISi speed to 25MHz or 33MHz the clock must be changed
from 40MHz to 50MHz or 64MHz respectively.
This is done by going to a static-free work station or putting some
aluminum foil down to work on.
1. Open up the Si by lifting the tabs at the back of the case.
2. Remove the Hard Disk by disconnecting the power and SCSI cables
spreading the tabs
3. Remove the flopy drive.
4. Remove the power supply by spreading the tab in front and lifting
the supply straight up and out.
5. Remove the fan by pressing the ears together at the back
side of the fan and lifting straight up and out.
6. Remove the Mother Board by spreading the tabs on the left and
right side of the board and sliding the board forward then
lifting the board out. (all connectors on the back of the
board must be removed first)
7. Desolder the 40MHz clock (the one closest to the memory modules).
This is not easy even for a skilled solderer.
8. Get an IC socket with the round pins and remove four of the pins
by pushing them up from the bottom with long nose pliers.
9. Put the four pins in the holes vacated by the clock and solder
them in.
10.Insert a 50MHz or 64MHz clock.
11.Put large power transistor heat sink's on the processor chip and
the other large chip just to the right of the processor and
figure some way to hold the heat sync's in place. I made a
simple clamp by putting a four inch screw up through the hole
in the board between the two chips. Mount the screw using
insulated washers. Screw a cross member down over the heat
sync's to hold them in place. Don't use too much pressure.
12. Put it all back together and go-for-it.
Disclaimer: this is only the procedure I used and is not authorized by anyone.
You are on your own for this procedure. I'm quite sure it will
void your warentee."

I've just built a valve preamp and use a diode/capacitor
voltage multiplier to step the 12vAC supply voltage up to approx
260vDV. As the load resistance increases
and hence the output voltage drops. I need as high an output
voltage as possible. (about 260v).
The circuit consists of seven voltage multiplier stages
(ie 14 diodes and 14 capacitors) each capacitor develops about 38v
across them
column2: and I take the output from across seven capacitors=260v.

column1: Each capacitor is 100mfd at 68v.
If I increase each of the capacitors rating (220-470mfd)
increase the RC constant
column2: and hence alleviate some of the problem.

column1: These capacitors are going to be a little expensive as I need 14 of
them
1. What would happen if I connected a 470mfd at 400v capacitor in parallel
with the output (and hence in parallel with the seven 100mfd capacitors)?
Will it
column3: increase the C in circuit and hence increase

column1: the RC time constant? If it does
column2: and my output voltage becomes more

column1: stable by doing this
column2: then I will have killed two birds with one stone...

column1: as I am experiencing some 50Hz ripple (and hence amp hum)
capacitor will 'smooth' this out.
and
2. Can anyone recomend a suitable value for an inductor (choke) to
be placed in the output line of the power supply to filter out
the 50Hz mains hum. Lowest resistance possible !

run... especially if 14 new large capacitors don't work as planned!)

Last-modified: 1993/4/15
FAQ for sci.crypt
This is the sixth of ten parts of the sci.crypt FAQ. The parts are
mostly independent
column2: but you should read the first part before the rest.

column1: We don't have the time to send out missing parts by mail
Notes such as ``[KAH67]'' refer to the reference list in the last part.
The sections of this FAQ are available via anonymous FTP to rtfm.mit.edu
as /pub/usenet/news.answers/cryptography-faq/part[xx].  The Cryptography
FAQ is posted to the newsgroups sci.crypt
every 21 days.
Contents:
* What is public-key cryptography?
* What's RSA?
* Is RSA secure?
* How fast can people factor numbers?
* What about other public-key cryptosystems?
* What is public-key cryptography?
In a classic cryptosystem
column2: we have encryption functions E_K and

column1: decryption functions D_K such that D_K(E_K(P)) = P for any plaintext
P. In a public-key cryptosystem
column2: E_K can be easily computed from some

column1: ``public key'' X which in turn is computed from K. X is published
that anyone can encrypt messages. If D_K cannot be easily computed
from X
column2: then only the person who generated K can decrypt messages.

column1: That's the essence of public-key cryptography
and Hellman in 1976.
In a classic cryptosystem
column2: if you want your friends to be able to

column1: send secret messages to you
column2: you have to make sure nobody other than

column1: them sees the key K. In a public-key cryptosystem
and you don't have to worry about spies.
This is only the beginning of public-key cryptography. There is an
extensive literature on security models for public-key cryptography
applications of public-key cryptography
mathematical technology behind public-key cryptography
* What's RSA?
RSA is a public-key cryptosystem defined by Rivest
Adleman.  For full details
column2: there is a FAQ available by ftp at

column1: RSA.COM. Here's a small example.
Plaintexts are positive integers up to 2^{512}. Keys are quadruples
(p
and d and e large numbers with (de - 1) divisible by (p-1)(q-1). We
define E_K(P) = P^e mod pq
Now E_K is easily computed from the pair (pq
anyone knows
column2: there is no easy way to compute D_K from the pair

column1: (pq
column2: e). So whoever generates K can publish (pq

column1: secret message to him; he is the only one who can read the messages.
* Is RSA secure?
Nobody knows. An obvious attack on RSA is to factor pq into p and q.
See below for comments on how fast state-of-the-art factorization
algorithms run. Unfortunately nobody has the slightest idea how to
prove that factorization---or any realistic problem at all
matter---is inherently slow. It is easy to formalize what we mean by
``RSA is/isn't strong''; but
``Exact definitions appear to be necessary only when one wishes to
prove that algorithms with certain properties do _not_ exist
theoretical computer science is notoriously lacking in such negative
results.''
* How fast can people factor numbers?
It depends on the size of the numbers. In October 1992 Arjen Lenstra
and Dan Bernstein factored 2^523 - 1 into primes
weeks of MasPar time. (The MasPar is a 16384-processor SIMD machine;
each processor can add about 200000 integers per second.) The
algorithm there is called the ``number field sieve''; it is quite a
bit faster for special numbers like 2^523 - 1 than for general numbers
n
column2: but it takes time only about exp(O(log^{1/3} n log^{2/3} log n)) in

column1: any case.
An older and more popular method for smaller numbers is the ``multiple
polynomial quadratic sieve''
log^{1/2} log n))---faster than the number field sieve for small n
but slower for large n. The breakeven point is somewhere between 100
and 150 digits
Factorization is a fast-moving field---the state of the art just a few
years ago was nowhere near as good as it is now. If no new methods are
developed
column2: then 2048-bit RSA keys will always be safe from

column1: factorization
column2: but one can't predict the future. (Before the number

column1: field sieve was found
column2: many people conjectured that the quadratic

column1: sieve was asymptotically as fast as any factoring method could be.)
* What about other public-key cryptosystems?"

1843|"Thanks to all who responded to my original post.  I got the number for
Western Digital tech support and determined that I need to upgrade the
BIOS to the Super BIOS.  It will handle hard drives with up to 16 read/
write heads and up to 1024 cylinders.  The upgrade is $15
check or money order.  Send to:
Western Digital Corporation
Technical Support Group
P.O. Box 19665
Irvine
The Super BIOS is for any WD XT hard drive controller card in the
WD1002 series.
The BIOS on my system would only handle up to 20mb drives.
The responses to my request for help follow my .sig.  Warning: It's long.
Keith

Ah
column2: finally a question I can answer.   I mess with this older

column1: stuff alot.   Kinda fun.  8)
First problem I can forsee is that the ST-251 will not be
compadible with that WD card unless it has the right bios rom.
Check the numbers on it.  It should be the only non-smt chip on
the board.  Slightly below center
column2: and left.    The bios should read

column1: If the last 3 digits are 013
Looks right.   W5 and W7 are factory jumped (with a trace) between
pins 1 and 2 to select the primary controller address.
Looks right.
[art deleted]
I notice you left out the S1 jumper table settings.   Those are
what control what drive the controller thinks it has.   If you have
5 + +    open
6 + +    open
7 + +    open
8 + +    open
4 + +    closed
3 + +    closed
2 + +    open
1 + +    open
Note:   those are how WD runs the numbers on the jumper block.
Top to bottom.   +'s represent the jumper pins.    Pins 3
select the first drive setting (drive 0) and pins 1
second drive (drive 1).
If you have the 62-000094 rom
to look up how to do it... I don't have the big book right here.
See above.  You might have problems if the S1 jumpers are not
right.   Also
column2: at the risk of being insulting

column1: are on right and good. 8).    On the jumper on the 251
to the opposite side of the drive.    It's one or the other.
The narrow data cable goes to J2.   I've thrown it on J3 a few
times and banged my head for a day.....
Dunno.    IBM roms had to be later than 10/27/82.   A quick way
to check is to boot dos and run debug.   Enter:
-d f000:fff5 fffc    (the - is the debug prompt)
This will return the rom date
If I oversimplified any of the above
just hard to know what caliber of person I'm talking to. 8).
-->   Bob Valentine  <--
--> ravalent@mailbox.syr.edu <--

If you are using a TWISTED 34-way cable then move the jumper
on your drive to the neighbouring pins   :8::::::.  Make sure that
the twisted cable is for a hard disk (and not a floppy disk) - the
coloured stripe (pin 1) should be furthest from the twist.
This may also help.

column1: NOTE 1:  AT&T 6300 - The AT&T 6300 and the AT&T 6300 PLUS
contain system BIOS chips that support the hard disk drive.
When using a Western Digital XT controller card the system will
not ""boot.""  To solve this problem
column2: one of the ROM BIOS chips

column1: must be disabled.  To disable the BIOS on your Western Digital
XT controller card
column2: you must remove the jumper at position W-3

column1: or add a jumper at position R-23 (depending on which model of XT
controller you are using).
NOTE 2:  TANDY 1000 SYSTEMS - The WD1002A-WX1
WDXT-GEN2 and the WD1004-27X can be modified to operate in
Tandy 1000 series computers
""A"" version.  These computers utilize an interrupt of 2 (IRQ2)
instead of IRQ5
column2: the IBM standard.  To modify the WD1002A-WX1 or

column1: the WD1002-27X to operate in these systems
etch between pin 1 and pin 2 at jumper position W-7.  Then
solder pin 2 and pin 3 at the position (W-7).  To complete the
modification
column2: a jumper must be added to position 7 of switch S-1

column1: (2 rows of 8 pins).  PLEASE NOTE THAT ANY PHYSICAL MODIFICATION
TO YOUR WESTERN DIGITAL HARD DISK CONTROLLER VOIDS THE WARRANTY
ON YOUR BOARD.  To modify the WD1004A-WX1
WD1004-27X for your Tandy 1000 system
be soldered to jumper position W-27.  This will change the
interrupt from IRQ5 to IRQ2.

At least I don't have a dog that you need worry about.
Last week while entering a sand/gravel covered intersection in the country
I caught something unkosher out of the corner of my eye (you know that
disgusting sensation when great
intimately acquaint itself with you-- kind of like knowing that that darkening
shadow around you just cannot possibly be anything even remotely good
it probably has something to do with a Boeing 747 behaving
speaking
column2: much like a brick).  Negotiating my way into this intersection that

column1: somehow reminded me of Daytona beach (sans H2O
column3: & babes) I manage to get a

column1: glance at my impending destiny.  Lucifer's own DOG.  Hell's secret blend
of canine-- Doberman and Rottweiler (it moved with the grace of a Doberman
yet had the hulk and jowels of the Rottweiler-- a creature with a definite
*wrong* end to be at).  The picture in my mirrors was fuzzy
mistaking the fangs and saliva trail.
To shorten a verbose tale
column2: my burly gaurdian-angels once again performed above

column1: and beyond the call of duty
column2: carried the bike through the sand-trap (I honestlyhave no idea how)
column3: and left the minion of Beelzebub with a face that

column1: suspiciously resembles a Metzler tread.  No blood
Moral: I'm not really sure
column2: but more and more I believe that bikers ought

column1: to be allowed to carry handguns.
-Erc.
C Eric Sundheim
GrandRapids

1851|"I'm a biker and a dog-lover.
First and foremost
column2: I want to mention some common sense.  If it's a choice

column1: between injuring/killing a dog or getting yourself injured/killed
only one rational decision.  Only the most insane animal rights kook would put
the dog first.
Second
column2: it's useful to learn how to read a dog's body language.  How you react

column1: to a dog who is chasing you because he thinks it's a game (and that you're
playing with him) is completely different from how you react to a dog which
has hostile intent.
Third
column2: it's useful to learn how to present yourself to a dog.  Dogs are social

column1: beasts
column2: and recognize a domination/submission hierarchy.  To a dog

column1: two types of fellow-creatures; that which he dominates
dominate him.  You need to unambiguously represent yourself as being of the
latter class.  You are God: you are easily angered and your anger is terrible.
But God is also amused by one who properly submits to His dominance
even on rare occasions dispense a kind word
rapture unforeseen) A Dog Bisquit!
Now
column2: how does that all relate to biking?  Well

column1: assume that most dogs who chase motorcycles do so because they think it's a
game
column2: and not out of overt hostility.  The MSF suggestion is a very good one;

column1: when you see the dog coming
column2: slow down so he determines a particular place of

column1: interception.  Just before you (and he) reach that spot
that when he reaches it you're already long gone.  Dogs take a few seconds to
react to new input
column2: and definitely cannot comprehend the acceleration that a

column1: motorcycle is capable of.
With a hostile dog
column2: or one which you repeatedly encounter

column1: may be necessary.  This is the face off.  First -- and there is very important
-- make sure you NEVER face off a dog on his territory.  Face him off on the
road
column2: not on his driveway.  If necessary

column1: newspaper
column2: etc. (something the beast will understand is something that will

column1: hurt him).  Stand your ground
column2: then slowly advance.  Your mental attitude is

column1: that you are VERY ANGRY and are going to dispense TERRIBLE PUNISHMENT.  The
larger the dog
Dogs will pick up anger
column2: just as they can pick up fear.  And

column1: are not on his home territory
column2: it may suddenly dawn on the dog that perhaps he

column1: is on your territory
column2: and that you are prepared to fight to the death.

column1: Most dogs will decide that it is a good idea to retreat to their own territory
where there is at least a home advantage.  They'll also observe that you are
satisfied by that retreat (gesture of submission) and thus they have escaped
punishment."

Let me first say that ""to believe that no gods exist"" is in fact
different than ""not believing in a god or gods"".
I will argue that your latter statement
does rest upon faith - that is
column2: if you are making a POSITIVE statement

column1: that ""no gods exist"" (strong atheism) rather than merely saying I don't
know and therefore don't believe in them and don't NOT believe in then
(weak atheism). Once again
column2: to not believe in God is different than saying

column1: I BELIEVE that God does not exist. I still maintain the position
after reading the FAQs
But first let me say the following.
We might have a language problem here - in regards to ""faith"" and
existence"". I
column3: maintain that God does not exist.

column1: To exist means to have being in space and time. God does not HAVE
being - God IS Being. Kierkegaard once said that God does not
exist
column2: He is eternal. With this said

column1: to debate the so called ""existence"" of God - and that is not what
I'm doing here. I believe that God is the source and ground of
being. When you say that ""god does not exist""
statement - but we obviously mean two different things by it. However
in what follows I will use the phrase ""the existence of God"" in it's
'usual sense' - and this is the sense that I think you are using it.
I would like a clarification upon what you mean by ""the existence of
God"".
We also might differ upon what it means to have faith. Here is what
faith
1a: allegiance to duty or a person: LOYALTY
b  (1): fidelity to one's promises
(2): sincerity of intentions
2a (1): belief and trust in and loyalty to God
(2): belief in the traditional doctrines of a religion
b  (1): firm belief in something for which there is no proof
(2): complete trust
3: something that is believed esp. with strong conviction; esp: a system
of religious beliefs
syn see BELIEF
One can never prove that God does or does not exist. When you say
that you believe God does not exist
column2: and that this is an opinion

column1: based upon observation""
column2: I will have to ask ""what observtions are

column1: you refering to?"" There are NO observations - pro or con - that
are valid here in establishing a POSITIVE belief. All observations
can only point you in a direction - a direction that we might even
be predisposed to (by predisposed I mean
partents ""believe in God"" also tend to). To actually draw a conclusion
about the ""existence"" or ""non-existence"" of God requires a leap - and
you have made this leap when you actively say ""I believe that God
does/does not exist"". Personally
column2: I think that both statements are

column1: misguided. Arguing over the ""existence"" of God is precisely the wrong way
to find Him (and yes
column2: I use ""Him"" because a personal God is the only

column1: viable concept (IMO) - if a person wants to use ""She"" go ahead. Of course
God is neither He nor She - but we have no choice but to
anthropomorphise. If you want me to explain myself further I'll be
glad to.)
And please
column2: if someone does not agree with me - even if they violently

column1: disagree - it's in no ones advantage to start name calling. If a person
thinks I've misunderstood something in the FAQs
I have not read them well enough
column2: just point out to me the error of my

column1: ways and I correct the situation. I'm interested in a polite and well
thought out discussion.

A method which will directly (almost) provide you with the information that
you require is that which is commonly used for coordinate measurements of
human body landmarks (eg. the SELSPOT system by SELSPOT AB
WATSMART System ??).  These use lateral photoeffect detectors [Lindholm and
Oberg
column3: 1980] to determine the position of a

column1: spot of light projected (using a camera lens) over its surface.  In escence
the detector is a large photodiode with four cathodes (one on each of the
four sides of the square detector crystal) and a single anode (the back of
the crystal).  A spot of light will produce currents which are proportional
to the position of the spot on the detector's face.  Let's try some ASCII
graphics in 2-D (so the detector has two cathodes to detect linear position)
-----   cathode 1         |       |  \
light >XXXXX|                            |        \_____ divider __ output
XXXXX|         --- gnd    |       |  /
XXXXX|         \ /        |       |/
XXXXX| anode              |
XXXXX                     |
----- cathode 2           |
If the dot of light from the LED is the ONLY source of light
of the projection is given by this circuit regardless of the level of illumina-
tion (the divider is used to normalize relative to total received power).  When
this circuit is used in the presence of other sources of light
tuning"" to it is to sample for a few msec the background signal
for an equal time and sample that signal separately.  The difference between
the two is the position of the LED.
Hamamatsu photonics sells linear and 2-D lateral photoeffect detectors
they also sell the required signal processing electronics.  The ready-made
systems by SELSPOT and others are NOT cheap ...
Lindholm
On-Line Movement Monitoring""
Woltring
ments in Two and Three Dimensional Space - A Preliminary Report""
thetics Research
Most probably this technique can provide you with a much more accurate
measurement than you need
column2: but I think that its simplicity beats scanning

column1: a quadrant detector with a pan/tilt system until you reach zero difference.
- David

among the best evidence that exists to rebut claims that the
Holocaust is a myth

a supervisory archivist for captured German records.  ""He was

column2: moved out of Berlin to what Himmler hoped

100 German secret police generals.  ""I also want to talk to you

Judenevakuierung"" or ""evacuation of the Jews.""  But archives

1905|"Obesssive Compulsive Disorder (not to be confused with Obsessive Compulsive
_Personality_ Disorder !) is an acute anxiety disorder characterized by
either obsessions (persistent intrusive thoughts that cause anxiety when
not entertained)
similarly cause intense psychological discomfort when resisted).
OCD is often associated with certain forms of depression.
Examples of obsessive thoughts are repeated impulses to kill a loved
one (though not accompanied by anger)
recurrent blasphemous thoughts.  Generally
or suppress the intrusive thoughts by engaging in other activities.
The individual realizes that the thoughts originate from the own mind
than being from an external source.
Examples of compulsive actions are constant repetitive hand washing
or other activity that is not realistically related to alleviating a
source of the anxiety.
In OCD
column2: the obsessions or compulsions are highly distressing to the

column1: individual
column2: take an hour or more per day

column1: daily routine and social relationships.
Treatments include psychotherapy
certain anti-depressants which have recently been found effective in alleviating
obsessions and compulsions.
The standard diagnostic code for OCD
column2: if you want to look it up in the

column1: DSM-III manual of psychiatric diagnosis is 300.30 .
kind regards

1908|The problems with Catholic liturgy are likely to continue for
some time.  The problem is
symbolic action - in other words Catholics do [or should] believe that
the _signs_ during the mass - Water
Relics
column2: etc - are real. That is the sprinkling of water bestows real

column1: almost tangible
column3: the Vestments are a real indication of real

column1: sacred time. The point of a _symbol_ is that it is understood by all
to be connected to an underlying REAL referent. This kind of thinking
precludes analysis; holy water is not holy because of anything
simply IS holy.
But
column2: modern westerners find it extremely difficult

column1: well- educated
column2: to think of the mass as a symbol. We are more likely

column1: to see it as a _sign_
column2: ie an action that represents grace

column1: could be replaced with other signs. In concrete terms
mass has become a commercial for God's grace rather than the real
thing. You can mess around with a commercial in a way you wouldn't
dare with the real thing [ask Coca-Cola Co.!]. These attitudes have
been encouraged by Liturgy workshops
on _how_ to do do liturgy
column2: have focused on how to create a meaning in

column1: liturgy. You can only create signs
column2: symbols have to come from God [or

column1: the heart
column2: or somewhere deeper than analysis. The most dramatic

column1: example of this shift in understanding has been in the treatment of
the sacred species [the consecrated host and wine]. Now
bread etc
column2: it is common to come away from the altar with hands covered

column1: in particles. If the Host is a sign of Grace
Catholics in the past would have been distraught at this real
desacration of the real symbol of Jesus' body.
Modern Catholic liturgy  is caught in this epistemological shift. We
try to perfrom the old rites
column2: but then we have some liturgomaniac

column1: priest get up and 'explain' what we are doing - so we stop doing it and
start pretending to do it. This is not a soul filling experience.
It doesn't help BTW that we have got stuck witha huge amount of two and
three chord ersatz-folk music [again a result of mis-analysis: complicated
tunes are in fact easier to remember than simple ones - this was the
genius of Wesley and the 19C Anglican hymn writers]. Taize' is only
slightly better.
What are we to do? Well I suggest rejecting the parish system if it
doesn't work for you. Search out a Church where the liturgy is well
prepared not well-explained. They exist in every city. This is not BTW
a matter of particular style: the music might be old or new. It is
the attitude of the church that counts. Also
liturgy - harking back to pre-Vatican II days
the Church will be socially conservative.
In NYC I can recommend:
Corpus Christi - W 12st St.

1927|"Archive-name: ripem/attacks
Last-update: 31 Mar 93 21:00:00 -0500
SOME POSSIBLE ATTACKS ON RIPEM
This is a living list of potential weaknesses to keep your eyes open
for when using RIPEM for secure electronic mail.  It does not go into
great detail
column2: and is almost certainly not exhaustive.  Obviously

column1: of the weaknesses are weaknesses of cryptographically secured mail in
general
column2: and will pertain to secure mail programs other than RIPEM.

column1: It is maintained by Marc VanHeyningen <mvanheyn@cs.indiana.edu>.  It
is posted monthly to a variety of news groups; followups pertaining
specifically to RIPEM should go to alt.security.ripem.
CRYPTANALYSIS ATTACKS
- Breaking RSA would allow an attacker to find out your private key
in which case he could read any mail encrypted to you and sign
messages with your private key.
RSA is generally believed to be resistant to all standard
cryptanalytic techniques.  Even a standard key (about 516 bits with
RIPEM) is long enough to render this impractical
huge investment in hardware or a breakthrough in factoring.
- Breaking DES would allow an attacker to read any given message
since the message itself is encrypted with DES.  It would not allow
an attacker to claim to be you.
DES has only 56 bits in its key
compromised by brute force with sufficient hardware
have such money to devote to simply read one message.  Since each
message has a different DES key
column2: the work for each message would

column1: remain high.
KEY MANAGEMENT ATTACKS
- Stealing your private key would allow the same benefits as breaking
RSA.  To safeguard it
column2: it is encrypted with a DES key which is derived

column1: from a passphrase you type in.  However
column2: if an attacker can get a copy

column1: of your private keyfile and your passphrase (by snooping network
packets
column3: or whatever) he could break the whole scheme.

column1: The main risk is that of transferring either the passphrase or the
private key file across an untrusted link.  So don't do that.  Run
RIPEM on a trusted machine
column2: preferably one sitting right in front of

column1: you.  Ideally
column2: your own machine in your own home (or maybe office)

column1: which nobody else has physical access to.
- Fooling you into accepting a bogus public key for someone else could
allow an opponent to deceive you into sending secret messages to him
rather than to the real recipient.  If the enemy can fool your
intended recipient as well
column2: he could re-encrypt the messages with

column1: the other bogus public key and pass them along.
It is important to get the proper public keys of other people.
The most common mechanism for this is finger; assuming the opponent
has not compromised routers or daemons or such
given a fair amount of trust.  The strongest method of key
authentication is to exchange keys in person; however
not always practical.  Having other people ""vouch for you"" by
signing a statement containing your key is possible
RIPEM doesn't have features for doing this as automatically as
PGP.  RIPEM does generate and check MD5 fingerprints of public keys
in the key files; they may be exchanged via a separate channel for
authentication.
PLAYBACK ATTACKS
- Even if an opponent cannot break the cryptography
still cause difficulties.  For example
with MIC-ONLY (a PEM mode which does not provide disclosure protection)
to Alice which says ""OK
column2: let's do that."" Your opponent intercepts

column1: it
column2: and now resends it to Bob
column3: who now has a message which is

column1: authenticated as from you telling him to do that.  Of course
interpret it in an entirely different context.  Or your opponent
could transmit the same message to the same recipient much later
figuring it would be seen differently at a later time.  Or the
opponent could change the Originator-Name: to himself
your public key as his
column2: and send a message hoping the recipient

column1: will send him return mail indicating (perhaps even quoting!) the
unknown message.
To defeat playback attacks
column2: the plaintext of each message should

column1: include some indication of the sender and recipient
identifier (typically the date).  A good front-end script for RIPEM
should do this automatically (IMHO).  As a recipient
sure that the Originator-Name: header and the sender indicated within
the plaintext are the same
column2: that you really are a recipient

column1: the message is not an old one.  Some this also can and should be
automated.  The author of this FAQ has made a modest attempt at
automating the process of generating and checking encapsulated
headers; the programs are included in the standard distribution in
the utils directory.
LOCAL ATTACKS
- Clearly
column2: the security of RIPEM cannot be greater than the security of

column1: the machine where the encryption is performed.  For example
UNIX
column2: a super-user could manage to get at your encrypted mail

column1: although it would take some planning and effort to do something like
replace the RIPEM executable with a Trojan horse or to get a copy of
the plaintext
In addition
column2: the link between you and the machine running RIPEM is

column1: an extension of that.  If you decrypt with RIPEM on a remote machine
which you are connected to via network (or
eavesdropper could see the plaintext (and probably also your
passphrase.)
RIPEM should only be executed on systems you trust
the extreme case
column2: RIPEM should only be used on your own machine

column1: which you have total control over and which nobody else has access
to
column2: which has only carefully examined software known to be free of

column1: viruses
column3: there's a very real trade-off between

column1: convenience and security here.
A more moderately cautious user might use RIPEM on a UNIX workstation
where other people have access (even root access)
security by keeping private keys and the (statically linked
course) executable on a floppy disk.
Some people will keep RIPEM on a multi-user system
in over an insecure line
column2: they will download the message to their

column1: own system and perform the RIPEM decryption there.  However
security provided by such a mechanism is somewhat illusory; since
you presumably type your cleartext password to log in
given away the store
column2: since the attacker can now log in as you and

column1: install traps in your account to steal your private key next time
you use it from a less insecure line.  This will likely remain the
situation as long as most systems use the rather quaint mechanism of
cleartext password authentication.
I find it nice to put a brief statement of how carefully I manage my
security arrangement in my .plan next to my public key
potential correspondents can be aware what level of precautions are
in place.  Some people use two keys
column2: a short one which is not

column1: carefully managed for ordinary use and a longer one which is treated
with greater care for critical correspondence.
UNTRUSTED PARTNER ATTACKS
- RIPEM's encryption will ensure that only a person with the private key
corresponding to the public key used to encrypt the data may read the
traffic.  However
column2: once someone with that key gets the message

column1: may always make whatever kind of transformations she wishes.  There
exist no cryptographic barriers to a recipient
ENCRYPTED message and converting it to a MIC-ONLY message
you and readable by anyone
column2: although RIPEM does not provide this

column1: functionality.  Indeed
column2: the latest PEM draft I have seen specifically

column1: states that such transformations should be possible to allow
forwarding functions to work."

Your logic certainly applies to standard investment strategies.  However
concept of a prize for a difficult goal is done for different reasons
suspect.  I'm not aware that Mr Orteig received any significant economic
benefit from Lindbergh's flight.  Modern analogies
column2: such as the prize for a

column1: human powered helicopter face similar arguments.  There is little economic
benefit in such a thing.  The advantage comes in the new approaches developed
and the fact that a prize will frequently generate far more work than the
equivalent amount of direct investment would.  A person who puts up $ X billion
for a moon base is much more likely to do it because they want to see it done
than because they expect to make money off the deal."

I'd recommend McDowell's ""Evidence that Demands a Verdict"" books (3 I
think) and  Manfred Brauch's ""Hard Sayings of Paul"".  He also may have
done ""Hard Sayings of Jesus"".  My focus would be for a new Christian to
struggle with his faith and be encouraged by the historical evidence
especially one who comes from a background which emphasizes knowable faith."

I am myself an SDA and I am in total agreement with what Darius has to say.
I also worship on Saturday to honor the Lord.  Your mention of ""[esteeming]
all days alike"" IMO has to do with the fast days observed by the Jews.  But
no matter how you interpret that passage
column2: I do accept your worship on Sunday

column1: as being done in honor of the Lord
column2: in contrast with what many of my fellow

column1: SDA believers may believe.  To me
to Saturday as the day to be kept in honor of creation and of God's
deliverance of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage.  To those who would
attempt to point out that my observance of Saturday is being legalistic
this is simply not the case.  Rather
column2: keeping Saturday allows me a full day

column1: to rest and contemplate God's goodness and grace.
The idea was introduced to me once that the reason Paul wanted the
Corinthians to lay aside money for the collection on the first day of the
week was because that was when they received their weekly wages.  Paul
wanted them to lay aside money for the collection as first priority
spending their money on other things.  I do not have any proof in front of
me for this though
column2: although it would explain why they would lay aside money

column1: in their homes instead of a meeting.
It would seem to me that you assume that the christians in the NT regularly
worshipped on the first day.  I assume that the christians in the NT
regularly worshipped on the seventh day.  But I agree with you that we only
have implications because the authors did assume the reader knew when worhip
was."

column1: 1967|I would like the opinion of netters on a subject that has been bothering my
wife and me lately: liturgy
column3: Catholic liturgy.  In the last few

column1: years it seems that there are more and more ad hoc events during Mass.  It's
driving me crazy!  The most grace-filled aspect of a liturgical tradition is
that what happens is something we _all_ do together
column2: because we all know how to

column1: do it.  Led by the priest
column3: which makes it a kind of dialogue we

column1: present to God.  But the best Masses I've been to were participatory prayers.
Lately
column2: I think the proportion of participation has fallen

column1: of sitting there and watching
column3: or generally being told what to do

column1: (which is necessary because no one knows what's happening next) is growing.
Example.  Last Sunday (Palm Sunday) we went to the local church.  Usually
on Palm Sunday
column2: the congregation participates in reading the Passion

column1: the role of the mob.  The theology behind this seems profound--when we say
Crucify him"" we mean it.  We did it
column2: and if He came back today we'd do it

column1: again.  It always gives me chills.  But last week we were ""invited"" to sit
during the Gospel (=Passion) and _listen_.  Besides the Orwellian ""invitation""
I was really saddened to have my (and our) little role taken away.  This seems
typical of a shift of participation away from the people
musicians
column3: and so on.  New things are introduced in the course of the

column1: liturgy and since no one knows what's happening
column2: the new things have to be

column1: explained
column2: and pretty soon instead of _doing_ a lot of the Mass we're just

column1: sitting there listening (or spacing out
column2: in my case) to how the Mass is about

column1: to be done.  In my mind
column2: I lay the blame on liturgy committees made up of lay

column1: experts""
column2: but that may not be just.  I do think that a liturgy committee has a

column1: bias toward doing something rather than nothing--that's just a fact of
bureaucratic life--even though a simpler liturgy may in fact make it easier for
people to be aware of the Lord's presence.
So we've been wondering--are we the oddballs
column2: or is the quality of the Mass

column1: going down?  I don't mean that facetiously.  We go to Mass every Thursday or
Friday and are reminded of the power of a very simple liturgy to make us aware
of God's presence.  But as far as the obligatory Sunday Masses...maybe I should
just offer it up :)  Has anyone else noticed declining congregational
participation in Catholic Masses lately?"

Many veterinarians feel that Lyme Disease in dogs is so easy to treat that
in an endemic area
column2: they often just give the appropriate antibiotics to dogs

column1: presenting with lameness
A recent paper (March 1993) has finally established that Lyme disease in dogs
can be reproduced in a controlled experimentaly setting.  This has been
an ellusive matter for researchers
column2: and is one of the fundamental requirements

column1: for many to acknowledge an agent as being causitive of a particular disease.
Up to now
column2: only the vaccine manufacturer has been able to ""prove"" that

column1: the disease exists.
This paper is noteworthy in two other regards:
1) None of the animals they infected were treated in any way.  The dogs
had episodes of lameness during a 6-8 week period which occurred 2-5
months after exposure.  After this period
clinical signs up to the 17 month observation period of the study.  So
these are proven
column2: clinically sick Lyme patients showing spontaneous

column1: recovery without the benefit of drug treatment. Of course
longer than 17 months will be necessary to be sure the disease doesn't
have the same chronicity that some see in humans.
2)  The addendum to the paper calls into question the techniques used by the
vaccine manufacturer to validate the vaccine.  Of course
the world to use the model they developed in order to test vaccine
efficacy.
Anyway
column2: maybe we will see some independent

column1: of this vaccine in the next year or so.

I don't think ""extra-scientific"" is a very useful phrase in a discussion
of the boundaries of science
column2: except as a proposed definiens.  Extra-rational

column1: is a better phrase.  In fact
column2: there are quite a number of well-known cases

column1: of extra-rational considerations driving science in a useful direction.
For example
column2: Pasteur discovered that racemic acid was a mixture of

column1: enantiomers (the origin of stereochemistry) partly because he liked a
friend's crank theory of chemical action.  The friend was wrong
Pasteur's discovery stood.  A prior investigator (Mitscherlich)
at the same phenomenon
column2: had missed a crucial detail; presumably because he

column1: lacked Pasteur's motivation to find something that distinguished racemic
acid from tartaric (now we say: d-tartaric) acid.
Again
column2: Pasteur discovered the differential fermentation of enantiomers

column1: (tartaric acid again) not because of some rational conviction
he was trying to produce yeast that lived on l-tartaric acid.  His notebooks
contained fantasies of becoming the ""Newton of mirror-image life
he never admitted publically.
Perhaps the best example is the discovery that DNA carries genes.  Avery
started this work because of one of his students
and Francophobe Canadian

column1: Most of Griffiths' critics were French
column2: which decided the issue for the

column1: student.  Avery told him to replicate Griffiths' work in vitro
student eventually did
column2: whereupon Avery was convinced and started the

1994|"  Correct. Most X servers use a version of  malloc(3)  which will not return
memory to the OS (ie. the X server might  free(3)  a Pixmap
not shrink).
Well
column2: part of the routines I mentioned do a dirty little trick to get around

column1: that problem. First
column2: I create the shared memory segment

column1: attach the X server
column2: and then remove (!) the segment. If you read the man

column1: pages on removing of shared memory segments
column2: you will see that the segment

column1: only dies after all attachments are gone.
Now
column3: that's one attachment gone (the OS cleans up for you)

column1: and since the X server notices the client has dies
including detaching from the segment: there goes the last attachment. No more
shared memory segment.
Terrible
Regards

If you are handy with a soldering iron
column2: the loopback plugs are easy to

column1: make.  On a serial RS-232 nine-pin port
column2: use a female DB-9 connector and

column1: connect pins 1 to 7 to 8; 2 to 3; and 4 to 6 to 9.  For serial RS-232
25-pin ports
column2: you'll need a female DB-25 connector with pins 1 to 7;

column1: 2 to 3; 4 to 5 to 8; 6 to 11 to 20 to 22; 15 to 17 to 23; and 18 to 25
connected.  To test a Centronics 25-pin parallel port
connect pins 1 to 13; 2 to 15; 10 to 16; 11 to 17; and 12 to 14 in a male
DB-25 connector.
-Stan Wszola

Maria was born on October 16th 1890 to Luigi and Assunta Goretti
the  eldest  daughter  in the family of seven. She was a cheerful
girl
column2: always imitating her parents.  She had but one disire

column1: one wish: to receive our Lord in the Blessed Sacrament.
The date was finally set for little Maria to receive our Lord  on
the feast of Corpus Christi. For Maria
nity as she  slowly  neared  the  great  day.   When  it  finally
arrived
column2: Fr. Jerome( the priest who was to celebrate the Mass and

column1: give the children their First Holy Communion) delivered a  sermon
on	the  immense love of Jesus Christ for them and the great love
we should have in return for Him. He then warmly  urged  them  to
die rather than commit a mortal sin.
Maria humbly approached the Altar of God and  received  the  Holy
Eucharist.	Her  only  sadness  was  the  thought of her father's
absence
column2: who died some time beforehand. As for the	rest  of  the

column1: day
column2: Maria remained under the spell of the divine visit; that is

column1: until
her thoughts changed to when she could go next to Holy Communion.
Thus ended the happiest day of Maria's life.
Over the next twelve months

mother went out into the fields in place of  her  husband
